As a consequence, he has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection to give himself any hope of returning to Atletico.\n\nBut Costa says his former club are being priced out of a move by the Blues.\n\n\"I've demonstrated I care for Atletico and have interest in playing for them,\" he told ESPN Brasil.\n\n\"But if Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me.\n\n\"I know that this (big effort) will happen, but if it's to pay the amount that Chelsea want it won't be possible.\"\n\nCosta has won two Premier League titles in three years at Chelsea, scoring 59 goals in 120 appearances. He has 52 Premier League goals.\n\nAsked the fee Chelsea are requesting, Costa said: \"I don't know, but my agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid (for Costa in July 2014).\n\n\"Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\n\n\"When I came to Chelsea they paid a lot less compared to what's being offered to them.\n\n\"I think they should take into account everything that I've done. It's not my fault that I'm not at the club. If it was down to me I'd be playing. It's already been one month. Holidays are good but it gets tiresome.\n\n\"I didn't provoke the situation, but now that it's come to this the club has to think in two ways.\n\n\"Of course they need to get something back, like I gave them on the pitch, but financial as well. After three years they will receive a fee higher than what they paid.\"\n\nAtletico coach Diego Simeone was quizzed about Costa during his press conference on Friday morning, but insisted his focus was solely on Saturday's LaLiga opener at Girona.\n\n\"Diego Costa is not our player. {"timeCrawl": "22:52:00", "uri": "711151629", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T22:52:00Z", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "source": {"title": "herald.co.zw", "uri": "herald.co.zw", "id": "5683"}, "url": "http://www.herald.co.zw/costa-sticks-to-his-guns/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "LONDON. -- Diego Costa has released a statement saying he will not return to Chelsea and he \"must return to Atletico Madrid\".\n\nCosta is currently in his native Brazil and has threatened to remain there rather than return to London, and then leave on a free transfer.\n\nSuch a scenario is not acceptable to Chelsea, though, who want the player to return to training and put himself in contention for selection.\n\nHis relationship with manager Antonio Conte has broken down since the Italian told him via text message that he was no longer needed at the club.\n\nCosta only has eyes for a return to Atletico, currently under a transfer embargo, and will seemingly do anything necessary to secure that move.\n\nIn the statement, Costa said: \"My destination has already been decided. I must return to Atletico Madrid.\n\n\"It turns out that there is the impasse that Chelsea do not want to release me. But I believe that this situation will be resolved now on my return to Spain.\"\n\nEarlier this week, Costa gave an interview to the Daily Mail in which he stated his desire to leave Chelsea, accusing them of treating him like a \"criminal\".\n\nHe said: \"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. Why won't they let me go if they don't want me?\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid'.\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\"\n\nChelsea boss Antonio Conte reportedly texted Costa in June, informing the striker he was not part of his future plans, and the striker has since remained in his native Brazil.\n\nThe 28-year-old's lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, said last week his client intended to hand in a formal transfer request and is considering legal {"timeCrawl": "11:06:00", "uri": "709180323", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:06:00Z", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "source": {"title": "waterford-news.ie", "uri": "waterford-news.ie", "id": "437"}, "url": "http://www.waterford-news.ie/2017/08/14/diego-costa-im-not-a-criminal-im-waiting-for-chelsea-to-set-me-free/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\" and is prepared to remain in exile in Brazil for a year.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain striker joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in July 2014 and has twice won the Premier League title during his three years at Stamford Bridge.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments and Conte has recently been reluctant to discuss Costa, describing the situation as \"the past\".\n\nChelsea have previously insisted the decision for Costa to leave this summer was made in January, with both the player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, aware.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free,\" the player told the Daily Mail. \"I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me.\n\n\"I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\"\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday's opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nCosta has two years remaining on the contract signed with Chelsea on his arrival from Atletico, but, after being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his expected arrival.\n\nThe striker, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe added: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nCosta hopes to sort his future out quickly but is prepared to miss a year of playing rather than move somewhere other than Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo until January.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I have rejected other offers,\" he added.\n\n\"If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nThe striker said he was happy at Stamford Bridge until Conte made it clear he had no future in the Italian's team.\n\nThe friction can be traced to January, when Costa missed the Premier League trip to Leicester after a rumoured behind-the-scenes row with Conte and his coaching staff following speculation over a mega-money move to China.\n\nConte publicly stated Costa's absence was due to a back injury, but Costa has now admitted it was for disciplinary reasons.\n\n\"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way,\" he added.\n\nCosta also says he was nearing a new contract with Chelsea at the time.\n\nHe added: \"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it.\"\n\nCosta was critical of Conte, saying the former Juventus and Italy boss \"doesn't possess charisma\" and expressing anger over the Italian's communication.\n\nHe added: \"There are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. {"timeCrawl": "11:05:00", "uri": "709180019", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:05:00Z", "sim": 0.8588235378265381, "source": {"title": "Breaking News.ie", "uri": "breakingnews.ie", "id": "325"}, "url": "http://www.breakingnews.ie/sport/soccer/diego-costa-im-not-a-criminal-im-waiting-for-chelsea-to-set-me-free-801972.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\" and is prepared to remain in exile in Brazil for a year.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain striker joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in July 2014 and has twice won the Premier League title during his three years at Stamford Bridge.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments and Conte has recently been reluctant to discuss Costa, describing the situation as \"the past\".\n\nChelsea have previously insisted the decision for Costa to leave this summer was made in January, with both the player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, aware.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free,\" the player told the Daily Mail. \"I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me.\n\n\"I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\"\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday's opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nCosta has two years remaining on the contract signed with Chelsea on his arrival from Atletico, but, after being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his expected arrival.\n\nThe striker, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe added: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nCosta hopes to sort his future out quickly but is prepared to miss a year of playing rather than move somewhere other than Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo until January.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I have rejected other offers,\" he added.\n\n\"If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nThe striker said he was happy at Stamford Bridge until Conte made it clear he had no future in the Italian's team.\n\nThe friction can be traced to January, when Costa missed the Premier League trip to Leicester after a rumoured behind-the-scenes row with Conte and his coaching staff following speculation over a mega-money move to China.\n\nConte publicly stated Costa's absence was due to a back injury, but Costa has now admitted it was for disciplinary reasons.\n\n\"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way,\" he added.\n\nCosta also says he was nearing a new contract with Chelsea at the time.\n\nHe added: \"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it.\"\n\nCosta was critical of Conte, saying the former Juventus and Italy boss \"doesn't possess charisma\" and expressing anger over the Italian's communication.\n\nHe added: \"There are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. {"timeCrawl": "12:26:00", "uri": "711436069", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:26:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chelsea-pricing-me-out-of-atletico-madrid-return-diego-costa-36045260.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36045259.ece/7effc/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-acbf8a60-ee75-4c4b-bf85-5684d1a0fbef_I1.jpg\n\nDiego Costa has pleaded with Chelsea to lower their asking price to allow him to return to Atletico Madrid.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain international signed for \u00a332million from Atletico in July 2014, agreeing a five-year contract, and wishes to return to the Spanish capital.\n\nSpeaking from his native Lagarto earlier this week, Costa criticised Chelsea and head coach Antonio Conte.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by a text message sent by Conte during the off-season.\n\nBut the Blues insist it was decided in January, with the striker and his agent, Jorge Mendes, that Costa could leave this summer.\n\nCosta still has two years remaining on his contract. As a consequence, he has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection to give himself any hope of returning to Atletico.\n\nBut Costa says his former club are being priced out of a move by the Blues.\n\n\"I've demonstrated I care for Atletico and have interest in playing for them,\" he told ESPN Brasil.\n\n\"But if Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me.\n\n\"I know that this (big effort) will happen, but if it's to pay the amount that Chelsea want it won't be possible.\"\n\nCosta has won two Premier League titles in three years at Chelsea, scoring 59 goals in 120 appearances. He has 52 Premier League goals.\n\nAsked the fee Chelsea are requesting, Costa said: \"I don't know, but my agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid (for Costa in July 2014).\n\n\"Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\n\n\"When I came to Chelsea they paid a lot less compared to what's being offered to them.\n\n\"I think they should take into account everything that I've done. It's not my fault that I'm not at the club. If it was down to me I'd be playing. It's already been one month. Holidays are good but it gets tiresome.\n\n\"I didn't provoke the situation, but now that it's come to this the club has to think in two ways.\n\n\"Of course they need to get something back, like I gave them on the pitch, but financial as well. After three years they will receive a fee higher than what they paid.\"\n\nAtletico coach Diego Simeone was quizzed about Costa during his press conference on Friday morning, but insisted his focus was solely on Saturday's LaLiga opener at Girona.\n\n\"Diego Costa is not our player. {"timeCrawl": "17:32:00", "uri": "709360098", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T17:32:00Z", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/diego-costa-must-return-to-chelsea-before-move-to-atletico-can-happen-36028907.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36028906.ece/109af/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-5d99b4c2-2b9b-4818-90ed-89ab7879d6b7_I1.jpg\n\nDiego Costa must renege on his promise to remain in Brazil and instead return to Chelsea to have any hope of securing his desired move to Atletico Madrid, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nCosta has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\" and insisting he is prepared to remain in exile for a year.\n\nBut it is understood that Chelsea want Costa, a player with two years remaining on his contract, to return to the club.\n\nThe Blues also expect the Brazil-born Spain striker to prove his fitness and make himself available for selection.\n\nAfter being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his anticipated arrival as he agitates for a return to Atletico.\n\nCosta, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe told the Daily Mail: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nChelsea do not have a reserve team, only age-group sides, and Costa has been given no indication he would be expected to train with them, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nCosta joined Chelsea from Atletico in July 2014 and has twice won the Premier League title during his three years at Stamford Bridge.\n\nHe has scored 59 goals - 52 in the Premier League - across 120 appearances for the Blues.\n\nThe 28-year-old claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments and Conte has recently been reluctant to discuss the player, describing the situation as belonging in \"the past\".\n\nChelsea have previously insisted the decision that Costa should leave this summer was made in January, with both the player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, aware.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free,\" Costa said.\n\n\"I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me.\n\n\"I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\"\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday, the full opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nCosta only wants to move to Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo and cannot register new players until January.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I have rejected other offers,\" he added.\n\n\"If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nThe striker said he was happy at Stamford Bridge until Conte made it clear he had no future in the team.\n\nThe friction can be traced to January, when Costa missed the Premier League trip to Leicester after a rumoured behind-the-scenes row with Conte and his coaching staff following speculation over a mega-money move to China.\n\nConte publicly stated Costa's absence was due to a back injury, but the player has now admitted it was for disciplinary reasons.\n\n\"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way,\" he added.\n\nCosta also says he was nearing a new contract with Chelsea at the time, but believes Conte put a halt to negotiations.\n\nCosta was critical of Conte, saying the former Juventus and Italy boss \"doesn't possess charisma\" and expressing anger over the Italian's communication.\n\nHe added: \"There are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. You should be honest and direct to someone's face.\"", "id": "9131341", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Diego Costa 'must return to Chelsea before move to Atletico can happen'", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36028906.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-5d99b4c2-2b9b-4818-90ed-89ab7879d6b7_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1669, "date": "2014-07-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 1678}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [{"wgt": 100, "id": 383, "label": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy", "uri": "dmoz/Sports/Fantasy"}], "time": "17:32:00"}

{"timeCrawl": "22:11:00", "uri": "708934339", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T22:11:00Z", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4787112/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "He says he will never delete the text and feels he has been treated like a 'criminal'\n\nMere moments have passed since Sam Vokes headed Burnley into a 3-0 first half lead at Chelsea when there is a knock on the door at Diego Costa's family home in north-eastern Brazil.\n\nSportsmail has arrived unannounced and uninvited but, standing on the doorstep of his childhood home, Chelsea outcast Costa puffs out his cheeks and shakes his head.\n\n'It's going well for Chelsea, isn't it?' he grimaces. 'The red card changed the game but anyway, you've come a long way and I have nothing to hide. Come on in.'\n\nDiego Costa invited Sportsmail into his family home for an exclusive interview on Saturday\n\nCosta was watching his Chelsea team being beaten at home in the Premier League by Burnley\n\nCosta spoke exclusively to Sportsmail's Adam Crafton about his future in football\n\nSo in we go, to be greeted with smiles and handshakes from Costa's parents, Jose de Jesus and Josileide, and a small entourage of family friends.\n\nHis father, known as Zeinha, is the man who named his son after Diego Maradona while Costa's elder brother is Jair, after Jairzinho, the Brazilian icon of the 1970 World Cup.\n\nPerching himself on a chair in the garden, Costa smiles ruefully: 'It's been a strange summer.' Strange is one word for it.\n\nAfter helping Chelsea to the Premier League title by scoring 20 goals in manager Antonio Conte's first season at the club, Costa finds himself 5,000 miles from Stamford Bridge on the opening weekend of the new campaign.\n\nCosta's summer began with a text message from Conte, informing him his Chelsea career was over. Costa has not been at Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May and, during a half-hour conversation, the striker delivers a blistering retort.\n\nHe accuses Chelsea of treating him 'like a criminal' and refuses to rule out legal action. He says he will always keep Conte's text message on his phone and claims the Chelsea manager 'lacks charisma'. Costa also accuses Conte of blocking his contract negotiations in January.\n\nCosta's summer began with a text from Antonio Conte, telling him his Chelsea career was over\n\nCosta says he has been fined several weeks' wages but is defying demands to return to train with the reserves. The Spain international insists he wants a transfer to Atletico Madrid resolved this month and that, meanwhile, he is ready to see out his Chelsea contract unpaid and train alone near his home in Brazil.\n\nJose Mourinho, Costa's former manager at Chelsea, once described Lagarto - the player's hometown - as so remote that it sits 'beyond the sunset'. Located 80 miles inland from the coastal city of Aracaju, the capital of the Brazilian state of Sergipe, it is a modest place of refuge.\n\nLagarto has just over 100,000 inhabitants and is known for its farms growing cassava and tobacco but Diego Costa is the biggest show in town.\n\nA life-size graffiti mural of Costa in Chelsea blue gleams on one streetside wall. Over the past month, images have emerged of Costa going for a Jet Ski ride with his dog, attending the circus and partying in an Atletico shirt.\n\nCosta's family home features plenty of trophies and awards from his playing career\n\nHis family have never moved house. 'Only renovated,' he grins. 'You don't forget where you came from.'\n\nThe mantelpiece bears mementos of life in England and Spain, including his trophy for making the PFA Team of the Year, man-of-the-match awards from games against Everton and Crystal Palace and the Zarra prize as the Spaniard who scored most goals in La Liga in 2014.\n\nAs the final moments of Chelsea's 3-2 defeat by Burnley play out, his father peeks round the door. Zeinha shakes his head. Costa says: 'They are two players down, to be fair, Dad.' Another friend pops by: 'Bring back Diego!' he laughs. Costa grimaces.\n\nAs Chelsea chase the game, Costa's intensity builds. David Luiz makes it 3-2 with two minutes left. Costa is off the settee and celebrating, dropping his phone.\n\n'The Premier League is the top. These moments, chasing a game, with seconds to spare. It's what we live for. You saw Arsenal against Leicester? Madness. Then Liverpool? 3-3, last minute! Rooney has scored for Everton!I wouldn't be human if I didn't miss those moments.'\n\n***\n\nThere are plenty of reminders of his time at Chelsea and in London, but Costa is now in Brazil\n\nThere are photos all over the Costa living room of Diego playing for Chelsea and in Spain\n\nFirst things first, Costa is not expecting an SOS plea from Conte to return. 'No,' he insists. 'You know that the manager doesn't want me.\n\n'I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n'If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying \"I miss you\" and that they love me.\n\n'I am always talking with the boys - particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp.\n\n'They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.'\n\nCosta is a hero in his home town, Lagarto, which sits 80 miles from the coast of Brazil\n\nHe is buying land to launch his own football school that will be called Balon de Oro\n\nLagarto has just over 100,000 inhabitants and is known for its cassava and tobacco farms\n\nSo Diego, where did it all go wrong? 'I cannot speak for other people, only for myself. I had a great season. I fought in every game until the last moment.'\n\nIt was not always a rose-tinted picture at Stamford Bridge. In January, Sportsmail revealed that Costa had been embroiled in a training-ground row with fitness coach Julio Tous.\n\nConte attributed Costa's absence from the next match at Leicester to a niggling back problem. 'No, no, no,' Costa insists. 'That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way.'\n\nThen rumours of a move to China surfaced. It was smoothed over but tensions simmered. Costa had been close to agreeing a new deal at the club.\n\n'In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n'His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change.\n\n'I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.'\n\nCosta admits his former Chelsea manager Jose Mourinho called this summer to say good luck\n\nMention of the word charisma brings us to Mourinho and Costa smiles warmly: 'Jose has called me, direct to my phone, just to check I am OK and to see how I am.\n\n'He wished me good luck. I never had any problems with Jose, we have a strong relationship. Everyone was very sad when things didn't work out in the end for him at Chelsea.'\n\nCosta takes out his mobile, responding to a friend. Here Costa is king, the boy made good but who never forgets his roots.\n\nHe is buying land to launch his own football school that will be called Balon de Oro, after the Ballon d'Or, and he is working closely with the local authorities to improve lives for young people.\n\nThe 28-year-old striker works every day in the gym with a personal trainer and has been spotted spending his evenings playing Buraco, a card game similar to rummy, with friends.\n\nCosta wants to return to Atletico Madrid, who he played for between 2010 and 2014\n\n'What is happening now with Chelsea is sad,' he says. 'The text message - I understand it when a coach wants a different player.\n\n'Alvaro Morata is a great player. He had a great season in Madrid and actually with the way this crazy transfer market is, I think they got a good price for a young and talented forward. He will triumph at Chelsea, but there are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. You should be honest and direct to someone's face.\n\n'I was with the Spain national team, alone in my room, when it came through. It was a shock to get it like that. I was showing it to my team-mates and they could not believe how he had done it.\n\n'I was angry at the time. Now I am more calm. I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop.'\n\nCosta insists Conte did not raise the issue with him after the 2-1 FA Cup final defeat by Arsenal. 'No, no, no. There was no conversation or talks. Conte has his mentality. He thinks it's the best way of working.\n\n'He arrived from an Italian league where everyone is very serious and arrived in a dressing room where there are maybe more jokes.\n\n'The worst bit of all this, it is for the fans. They have always treated me so well, always, always. For this, I am sad. I hope they understand things happen in football. Conte is a great coach. He deserves to be where he is but it's his opinion. He has his reasons.'\n\n****\n\nCosta says he is still in close contact with his team mates at Chelsea, including David Luiz\n\nCosta says he gets WhatsApp messages from likes of Cesc Fabregas saying they miss him\n\nCosta has helped fire Chelsea to two Premier League titles in three years in England\n\nCosta may offer his gratitude to supporters but matters have threatened to turn nasty. His lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, has warned that Costa will use 'all legal mechanisms' to force a transfer and alleged Conte's conduct amounted to 'discriminatory behaviour'.\n\nCosta says legal proceedings are yet to begin, explaining: 'At the moment, no. I want people to do things the right way.\n\n'Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n'My desire is to go to Atletico (where he played from 2010-14). I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, \"If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid\".\n\n'I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n'Diego Simeone (Atletico manager) wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.'\n\nCosta accuses Conte of lacking charisma, and of being cold and distant with his players\n\nChelsea, he alleges, have reduced him to the status of a 'criminal' - 'They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.'\n\nChelsea have asked Costa back for training and their stance remains that he is still their player and they expect him to return.\n\nCosta's defiance has already cost him. 'They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\n\n'I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live. I'm here with my parents and people who respect me.'\n\nWould Costa ever return or would he consider a move to another English club? 'If I have to I will stay in Brazil,' he says.\n\nCosta says he will never delete Conte's text and feels he has been treated like a 'criminal'\n\n'I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\n\n'At the start of summer, they gave me an extra week of holiday. Then a week later they called to see where I was but by then the team was in Asia on tour, so I could go back and not have any contact with the boys.\n\n'That seems a very bad and ugly life. It doesn't respect what I have done for the club. I am here with people who love me. I want the fans to know I still care deeply about them but I'm not going back to be separated like that.\n\n'I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.'", "id": "8972762", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-13", "title": "DIEGO The 28-year-old is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nStandard Sport understands that Chelsea want Costa to honour the terms of his contract and return to training in order to get himself match fit and available for selection for Antonio Conte's Premier League champions.\n\nWhile Chelsea are willing to let the Spain international go if the club agrees a transfer fee with Atletico, the Blues expect Costa to act in a professional manner as he seeks a Stamford Bridge exit. Chelsea want \u00a350m for the forward, but Atletico have only offered \u00a326m so far.\n\nThe move is also further complicated by the fact that Atletico cannot register new players until January due to a Fifa transfer ban.\n\nCosta's potential return to Chelsea does not represent a U-turn by Conte regarding the striker's future. It has been reported Chelsea have fined him two weeks' wages, but the club are refusing to confirm the size of fine.\n\nHe is paid \u00a3150,000-a-week and has been AWOL for four weeks so far.\n\nCosta told the Daily Mail: \"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. {"timeCrawl": "09:40:00", "uri": "709143021", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T09:40:00Z", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "source": {"title": "Capital News", "uri": "capitalfm.co.ke", "id": "333"}, "url": "http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/sports/2017/08/14/im-no-criminal-costa-blasts-chelsea/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Shares\n\nChelsea's Diego Costa looked to be on the brink of leaving Chelsea for the Chinese Super League in January, but stayed put and contributed 20 goals to their Premier League title success\n\nLONDON, United Kingdom, Aug 14-Out-of-favour Chelsea striker Diego Costa has launched an angry broadside against both the club and manager Antonio Conte, accusing them of treating him like a \"criminal\".\n\nCosta, 28, has been informed by Conte that he has no future at the club and having been frozen out of the first-team squad, the Brazil-born Spain international has gone home to Brazil.\n\nHe says Chelsea \"want to sell me to China\", but has reiterated his desire to return to former club Atletico Madrid, who are under a transfer ban until January.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go,\" Costa said in an interview published in Monday's Daily Mail.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off, but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here.\n\n\"So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nCosta was particularly scathing in his criticism of Conte, who led Chelsea to the Premier League title in his first season at Stamford Bridge.\n\nDiego Costa says Antonio Conte no longer wants him at Chelsea. PHOTO/SKY.\n\n\"I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that. But as a person -- no,\" said Costa, who was speaking in his hometown of Lagarto in northeastern Brazil.\n\n\"He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nFaced with Atletico's inability to recruit players, Costa said he would rather spend a year not playing than join another club.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico,\" he said. \"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\"\n\nChelsea opened their title defence in disastrous fashion on Saturday, losing 3-2 at home to Burnley, with Costa's replacement Alvaro Morata coming off the bench to score.\n\nShares", "id": "9045629", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "'I'm no criminal!' {"timeCrawl": "09:20:00", "uri": "709133898", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T09:20:00Z", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/diego-costa-i-am-not-a-criminal-and-chelsea-should-set-me-free-36028907.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36028906.ece/109af/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-5d99b4c2-2b9b-4818-90ed-89ab7879d6b7_I1.jpg\n\nDiego Costa has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\" and is prepared to remain in exile in Brazil for a year.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain striker joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in July 2014 and has twice won the Premier League title during his three years at Stamford Bridge.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments and Conte has recently been reluctant to discuss Costa, describing the situation as \"the past\".\n\nChelsea have previously insisted the decision for Costa to leave this summer was made in January, with both the player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, aware.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free,\" the player told the Daily Mail. \"I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me.\n\n\"I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\"\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday's opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nCosta has two years remaining on the contract signed with Chelsea on his arrival from Atletico, but, after being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his expected arrival.\n\nThe striker, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe added: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nCosta hopes to sort his future out quickly but is prepared to miss a year of playing rather than move somewhere other than Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo until January.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I have rejected other offers,\" he added.\n\n\"If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nThe striker said he was happy at Stamford Bridge until Conte made it clear he had no future in the Italian's team.\n\nThe friction can be traced to January, when Costa missed the Premier League trip to Leicester after a rumoured behind-the-scenes row with Conte and his coaching staff following speculation over a mega-money move to China.\n\nConte publicly stated Costa's absence was due to a back injury, but Costa has now admitted it was for disciplinary reasons.\n\n\"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way,\" he added.\n\nCosta also says he was nearing a new contract with Chelsea at the time.\n\nHe added: \"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it.\"\n\nCosta was critical of Conte, saying the former Juventus and Italy boss \"doesn't possess charisma\" and expressing anger over the Italian's communication.\n\nHe added: \"There are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. {"timeCrawl": "23:13:00", "uri": "711158118", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:13:00Z", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "source": {"title": "Herald Sun", "uri": "heraldsun.com.au", "id": "1228"}, "url": "http://www.heraldsun.com.au/sport/football/chelsea-transfer-news-diego-costa-atletico-madrid-everton/news-story/d5162170b4b9a81302251f0cf897270d", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "DIEGO Costa has released a statement saying he will not return to Chelsea and he \"must return to Atletico Madrid\".\n\nCosta is currently in his native Brazil and has threatened to remain there rather than return to London, and then leave on a free transfer.\n\nSuch a scenario is not acceptable to Chelsea, though, who want the player to return to training and put himself in contention for selection.\n\nIn the statement, Costa said: \"My destination has already been decided. I must return to Atletico Madrid.\n\n\"It turns out that there is the impasse that Chelsea do not want to release me. But I believe that this situation will be resolved now on my return to Spain.\"\n\nChelsea boss Antonio Conte reportedly texted Costa in June informing the striker he was not part of his future plans, and the striker has since remained in his native Brazil.\n\nThe 28-year-old's lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, said last week his client intended to hand in a formal transfer request and is considering legal action against Chelsea in order to force through a move to former club Atletico.\n\nChelsea's stance remains unchanged from Monday in that they want Costa to return to the club, return to training, get match fit and put himself in contention for selection.\n\nAtletico Madrid captain Gabi has weighed into the saga, saying Costa should \"respect\" Chelsea's badge even though he wants to leave.\n\nGabi has urged former team-mate Costa not to dishonour Chelsea in his attempts to force through a move, though.\n\n\"From what I know, Atletico Madrid want to sign him and he wants to join,\" Gabi said at a press conference.\n\n\"But of course, there is Chelsea in the middle and when you are part of a club you must respect the badge and try and leave in the best way.\"\n\nMidfielder Koke added: \"If Costa joins then he will help the team as he always did, we know he is a great player but right now he is a Chelsea player and I cannot tell you any more.\"\n\nMeanwhile, if the impasse continues, Everton have emerged as a random solution.\n\nToffees manager Ronald Koeman has admitted he would be open to signing Chelsea forward Diego Costa on loan.\n\nCosta is surplus to requirements at Chelsea, but has been told he must return to training despite having no future at Stamford Bridge.\n\nAtletico are unable to register any new players this summer having had their appeal against their transfer ban rejected by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) in June, meaning Costa would not be able to feature until January if he did complete a move back to the club.\n\nHaving secured the \u00a345m club-record signing of midfielder Gylfi Sigurdsson on Wednesday, Koeman has set his sights on adding another striker to his squad and hinted at a possible move for Costa.\n\nWhen asked whether further signings would be \"permanent or temporary\", Koeman said: \"Is this about Costa?\n\n\"Of course you like to sign players for the future, but if you can get the best one that way, then why not?\"\n\n\"That's for six months, the season, two years.\n\n\"It's difficult \u00adbecause it needs to be a quality player, or a young player who can develop or improve.\n\n\"We have the possibility maybe to sign good players, but we don't play in the Champions League - and that sometimes makes things very difficult.\"\n\nRead more at Sky Sports {"timeCrawl": "14:30:00", "uri": "709274927", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T14:30:00Z", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "source": {"title": "ProSoccerTalk", "uri": "soccer.nbcsports.com", "id": "886"}, "url": "http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2017/08/14/cristiano-ronaldo-handed-five-game-ban-for-pushing-referee/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa didn't hold back in an interview with the Daily Mail who traveled to Brazil to track him down.\n\nCurrently hanging out at his family home in Lagarto in the north east of the country, Costa was watching Chelsea's 3-2 defeat to Burnley on the opening day of the season sat on the sofa while family members would glance into the room and shake their heads in disbelief.\n\nCosta, 28, made plenty of things clear in the outrageous interview as he aimed to set the record straight, stating he has already been fined several weeks wages by Chelsea, that he couldn't believe Antonio Conte text him saying he was no longer needed at the club and he also made it clear he wants to rejoin his former club Atletico Madrid.\n\nWhat did we actually learn from Costa's side of the story?\n\nBelow are the main takeaways from what he said as his future at Chelsea appears to be over, at least while Conte is boss, which may not be for much longer if the Blues continue their poor form throughout preseason and to start the Premier League season...\n\nCosta almost signed a new Chelsea deal in January before he was left out of the squad for a game at Leicester following a training ground incident\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\"\n\nAlthough Conte seems to be adored universally, Costa says that's far from the case with Chelsea's squad\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nCosta is holding out for a move to Atletico Madrid, who are banned from signing new players until January 2018, but Chelsea want to sell him to the Chinese Super League. His lawyer is also talking about taking action against Conte's \"discriminatory behavior\"\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing. My desire is to go to Atletico [Madrid]. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.' I have rejected other offers.\n\n\"They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most. Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\nAs far as Costa is concerned he has no future at Chelsea, plus he also claims his teammates send him messages of support\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying 'I miss you' and that they love me. I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\nIf a move to Atletico doesn't materialize, Costa is fine with staying in Brazil for a year\n\n\"If I have to I will stay in Brazil. I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say. At the start of summer, they gave me an extra week of holiday. Then a week later they called to see where I was but by then the team was in Asia on tour, so I could go back and not have any contact with the boys.\n\n\"That seems a very bad and ugly life. It doesn't respect what I have done for the club. I am here with people who love me. I want the fans to know I still care deeply about them but I'm not going back to be separated like that. I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\"\n\nCosta will continue to be fined by Chelsea for staying in Brazil and training there on his own instead of with Chelsea's reserves, but that's what he intends to do unless the situation changes\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that. They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me. I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. {"timeCrawl": "12:11:00", "uri": "711429412", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:11:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4802456/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "Aug 18 (Reuters) - Chelsea striker Diego Costa has accused the club of pricing him out of a move back to Atletico Madrid in his continuing stand-off with manager Antonio Conte.\n\nThe Spanish international is determined to rejoin former side Atletico despite the La Liga club being subject to a transfer ban preventing them from registering players until January.\n\nCosta has not played for Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May, following which he claims manager Antonio Conte sent him a text telling him he was not in his plans for the new season.\n\nChelsea say that was made clear to him as early as January.\n\nHe has accused the Premier League club of treating him like a \"criminal\" and has said he was willing to see out the remaining two years of his deal unpaid in Brazil.\n\n\"My destination is already set,\" Costa was quoted as saying by Brazilian newspaper O Globo. \"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season.\"\n\nAtletico are banned from signing players in this window as punishment for signing minors.\n\nCosta has remained in Brazil and been fined by Chelsea for not returning to pre-season training.\n\nIn a later interview with ESPN Brasil he accused the club of demanding too high a fee for him.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid,\" he said. Chelsea signed Costa from Atletico for \u00a332 million in July 2014.\n\n\"My agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near. Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\n\n\"I think they (Chelsea) should take into account everything that I've done. It's not my fault that I'm not at the club. If it was down to me I'd be playing. It's already been one month. Holidays are good but it gets tiresome.\"\n\nWith less than two weeks until the transfer window closes, Costa is now concerned that he may have to consider other options.\n\n\"If Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me,\" he said.\n\nConte, who has been reluctant to discuss the issue in public recently, will face further questions at his news conference on Friday ahead Sunday's Premier League game against Tottenham Hotspur.\n\n(Reporting by Shrivathsa Sridhar in Bengaluru; Additional reporting by Steve Tongue. {"timeCrawl": "12:44:00", "uri": "711443860", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:44:00Z", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "source": {"title": "Economic Times", "uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "id": "305"}, "url": "http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/sports/costa-accuses-chelsea-of-pricing-him-out-of-atletico-move/articleshow/60119899.cms", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "The Spanish international is determined to rejoin former side Atletico despite the La Liga club being subject to a transfer ban preventing them from registering players until January.\n\nCosta has not played for Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May, following which he claims manager Antonio Conte sent him a text telling him he was not in his plans for the new season.\n\nChelsea say that was made clear to him as early as January.\n\nHe has accused the Premier League club of treating him like a \"criminal\" and has said he was willing to see out the remaining two years of his deal unpaid in Brazil.\n\n\"My destination is already set,\" Costa was quoted as saying by Brazilian newspaper O Globo. \"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season.\"\n\nAtletico are banned from signing players in this window as punishment for signing minors.\n\nCosta has remained in Brazil and been fined by Chelsea for not returning to pre-season training.\n\nIn a later interview with ESPN Brasil he accused the club of demanding too high a fee for him.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid,\" he said. Chelsea signed Costa from Atletico for \u00a332 million in July 2014.\n\n\"My agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near. Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\n\n\"I think they (Chelsea) should take into account everything that I've done. It's not my fault that I'm not at the club. If it was down to me I'd be playing. It's already been one month. Holidays are good but it gets tiresome.\"\n\nWith less than two weeks until the transfer window closes, Costa is now concerned that he may have to consider other options.\n\n\"If Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me,\" he said.\n\nConte, who has been reluctant to discuss the issue in public recently, will face further questions at his news conference on Friday ahead Sunday's Premier League game against Tottenham Hotspur.", "id": "9894590", {"timeCrawl": "22:51:00", "uri": "709481431", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T22:51:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "herald.co.zw", "uri": "herald.co.zw", "id": "5683"}, "url": "http://www.herald.co.zw/im-being-treated-like-a-criminal-costa/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "LAGARTO. - Mere moments have passed since Sam Vokes headed Burnley into a 3-0 first half lead at Chelsea when there is a knock on the door at Diego Costa's family home in north-eastern Brazil.\n\nSportsmail has arrived unannounced and uninvited but, standing on the doorstep of his childhood home, Chelsea outcast Costa puffs out his cheeks and shakes his head.\n\n\"It's going well for Chelsea, isn't it?\" he grimaces. The red card changed the game but anyway, you've come a long way and I have nothing to hide. Come on in.\"\n\nSo in we go, to be greeted with smiles and handshakes from Costa's parents, Jose de Jesus and Josileide, and a small entourage of family friends.\n\nHis father, known as Zeinha, is the man who named his son after Diego Maradona while Costa's elder brother is Jair, after Jairzinho, the Brazilian icon of the 1970 World Cup. Perching himself on a chair in the garden, Costa smiles ruefully: \"It's been a strange summer.\" Strange is one word for it.\n\nAfter helping Chelsea to the English Premier League title by scoring 20 goals in manager Antonio Conte's first season at the club, Costa finds himself 5 000 miles from Stamford Bridge on the opening weekend of the new campaign.\n\nCosta's summer began with a text message from Conte, informing him his Chelsea career was over.\n\nCosta has not been at Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May and, during a half-hour conversation, the striker delivers a blistering retort.\n\nHe accuses Chelsea of treating him \"like a criminal\" and refuses to rule out legal action.\n\nHe says he will always keep Conte's text message on his phone and claims the Chelsea manager \"lacks charisma\". Costa also accuses Conte of blocking his contract negotiations in January.\n\nCosta says he has been fined several weeks' wages but is defying demands to return to train with the reserves. The Spain international insists he wants a transfer to Atletico Madrid resolved this month and that, meanwhile, he is ready to see out his Chelsea contract unpaid and train alone near his home in Brazil.\n\nJose Mourinho, Costa's former manager at Chelsea, once described Lagarto - the player's hometown - as so remote that it sits \"beyond the sunset\".\n\nLocated 80 miles inland from the coastal city of Aracaju, the capital of the Brazilian state of Sergipe, it is a modest place of refuge. Lagarto has just over 100 000 inhabitants and is known for its farms growing cassava (a root vegetable) and tobacco but Diego Costa is the biggest show in town.\n\nA life-size graffiti mural of Costa in Chelsea blue gleams on one streetside wall. Over the past month, images have emerged of Costa going for a Jet Ski ride with his dog, attending the circus and partying in an Atletico shirt.\n\nHis family have never moved house. \"Only renovated,\" he grins. \"You don't forget where you came from.\"\n\nThe mantelpiece bears mementoes of life in England and Spain, including his trophy for making the PFA Team of the Year, man-of-the-match awards from games against Everton and Crystal Palace and the Zarra prize as the Spaniard who scored most goals in the Spanish La Liga in 2014.\n\nAs the final moments of Chelsea's 3-2 defeat by Burnley play out, his father peeks round the door. Zeinha shakes his head. Costa says: \"They are two players down, to be fair, Dad.\" Another friend pops by: \"Bring back Diego!\" he laughs. Costa grimaces.\n\nAs Chelsea chase the game, Costa's intensity builds. David Luiz makes it 3-2 with two minutes left. Costa is off the settee and celebrating, dropping his phone.\n\n\"The Premier League is the top. These moments, chasing a game, with seconds to spare. It's what we live for. You saw Arsenal against Leicester? Madness. Then Liverpool? 3-3, last minute! Rooney has scored for Everton! I wouldn't be human if I didn't miss those moments.\"\n\nFirst things first, Costa is not expecting an SOS plea from Conte to return. \"No,\" he insists. \"You know that the manager doesn't want me.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\n\n\"If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying 'I miss you' and that they love me.\n\n\"I am always talking with the boys - particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\nSo Diego, where did it all go wrong?\n\n\"I cannot speak for other people, only for myself. I had a great season. I fought in every game until the last moment.\"\n\nIt was not always a rose-tinted picture at Stamford Bridge. In January, Sportsmail revealed that Costa had been embroiled in a training-ground row with fitness coach Julio Tous. Conte attributed Costa's absence from the next match at Leicester to a niggling back problem. \"No, no, no,\" Costa insists. \"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and for not behaving in the best way.\" Then rumours of a move to China surfaced. It was smoothed over but tensions simmered. Costa had been close to agreeing a new deal at the club.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change.\n\n\"I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nMention of the word charisma brings us to Mourinho and Costa smiles warmly: \"Jose has called me, direct to my phone, just to check I am OK and to see how I am.\n\n\"He wished me good luck. I never had any problems with Jose, we have a strong relationship. Everyone was very sad when things didn't work out in the end for him at Chelsea.\"\n\nCosta takes out his mobile, responding to a friend. Here Costa is king, the boy made good but who never forgets his roots. He is buying land to launch his own football school that will be called Balon de Oro, after the Ballon d'Or, and he is working closely with the local authorities to improve lives for young people.\n\nThe 28-year-old striker works every day in the gym with a personal trainer and has been spotted spending his evenings playing Buraco, a card game similar to rummy, with friends.\n\n\"What is happening now with Chelsea is sad,\" he says.\n\n\"The text message - I understand it when a coach wants a different player.\n\n\"Alvaro Morata is a great player. He had a great season in Madrid and actually with the way this crazy transfer market is, I think they got a good price for a young and talented forward. He will triumph at Chelsea, but there are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. You should be honest and direct to someone's face.\n\n\"I was with the Spain national team, alone in my room, when it came through. It was a shock to get it like that. I was showing it to my team-mates and they could not believe how he had done it.\n\n\"I was angry at the time. Now I am more calm. I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop.\"\n\nCosta insists Conte did not raise the issue with him after the 2-1 FA Cup final defeat by Arsenal. \"No, no, no. There was no conversation or talks. Conte has his mentality. He thinks it's the best way of working.\n\n\"He arrived from an Italian league where everyone is very serious and arrived in a dressing room where there are maybe more jokes.\n\n\"The worst bit of all this, it is for the fans. They have always treated me so well - always, always. For this, I am sad. I hope they understand things happen in football.\n\n\"Conte is a great coach. He deserves to be where he is but it's his opinion. He has his reasons.\" Costa may offer his gratitude to Chelsea supporters but matters have threatened to turn nasty.\n\nHis lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, has warned that Costa will use \"all legal mechanisms\" to force a transfer and alleged Conte's conduct amounted to 'discriminatory behaviour'.\n\nCosta says legal proceedings are yet to begin, explaining: \"At the moment, no. I want people to do things the right way.\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico (where he played from 2010-14). I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid'.\n\n\"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to - not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone (Atletico manager) wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\nChelsea, he alleges, have reduced him to the status of a \"criminal\".\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys.\n\n\"I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\"\n\nCosta's defiance has already cost him. \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\n\n\"I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live. I'm here with my parents and people who respect me.\"\n\nWould Costa ever return or would he consider a move to another English club? \"If I have to I will stay in Brazil,\" he says.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\n\n\"At the start of summer, they gave me an extra week of holiday. Then a week later they called to see where I was but by then the team was in Asia on tour, so I could go back and not have any contact with the boys. 'That seems a very bad and ugly life. It doesn't respect what I have done for the club. I am here with people who love me. I want the fans to know I still care deeply about them but I'm not going back to be separated like that.\n\n\"I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\" - Mailonline.", "id": "9174789", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", {"timeCrawl": "09:32:00", "uri": "709139324", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T09:32:00Z", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "source": {"title": "Daily Nation", "uri": "nation.co.ke", "id": "1306"}, "url": "http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/football/Im-no-criminal-Costa-blasts-Chelsea/1102-4056746-fnyr2nz/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "He says Chelsea \"want to sell me to China\", but has reiterated his desire to return to former club Atletico Madrid, who are under a transfer ban until January.\n\nOut-of-favour Chelsea striker Diego Costa has launched an angry broadside against both the club and manager Antonio Conte, accusing them of treating him like a \"criminal\".\n\nCosta, 28, has been informed by Conte that he has no future at the club and having been frozen out of the first-team squad, the Brazil-born Spain international has gone home to Brazil.\n\nHe says Chelsea \"want to sell me to China\", but has reiterated his desire to return to former club Atletico Madrid, who are under a transfer ban until January.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go,\" Costa said in an interview published in Monday's Daily Mail.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off, but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here.\n\n\"So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nCosta was particularly scathing in his criticism of Conte, who led Chelsea to the Premier League title in his first season at Stamford Bridge.\n\n\"I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that. But as a person -- no,\" said Costa, who was speaking in his hometown of Lagarto in northeastern Brazil.\n\n\"He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nFaced with Atletico's inability to recruit players, Costa said he would rather spend a year not playing than join another club.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico,\" he said. \"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\"\n\nAlthough Conte seems to be adored universally, Costa says that's far from the case with Chelsea's squad\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nCosta is holding out for a move to Atletico Madrid, who are banned from signing new players until January 2018, but Chelsea want to sell him to the Chinese Super League. His lawyer is also talking about taking action against Conte's \"discriminatory behavior\"\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing. My desire is to go to Atletico [Madrid]. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.' I have rejected other offers.\n\n\"They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most. Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\nAs far as Costa is concerned he has no future at Chelsea, plus he also claims his teammates send him messages of support\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying 'I miss you' and that they love me. I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\nIf a move to Atletico doesn't materialize, Costa is fine with staying in Brazil for a year\n\n\"If I have to I will stay in Brazil. I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say. At the start of summer, they gave me an extra week of holiday. Then a week later they called to see where I was but by then the team was in Asia on tour, so I could go back and not have any contact with the boys.\n\n\"That seems a very bad and ugly life. It doesn't respect what I have done for the club. I am here with people who love me. I want the fans to know I still care deeply about them but I'm not going back to be separated like that. I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\"\n\nCosta will continue to be fined by Chelsea for staying in Brazil and training there on his own instead of with Chelsea's reserves, but that's what he intends to do unless the situation changes\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that. They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me. I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. {"timeCrawl": "08:43:00", "uri": "709662459", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T08:43:00Z", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chelsea/costa-must-return-to-chelsea-to-have-hope-of-atletico-move-36032828.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/incoming/article36032964.ece/c1008/AUTOCROP/h342/24781255%20%201039.jpg\n\nDiego Costa must renege on his promise to remain in Brazil and instead return to Chelsea to have any hope of securing his desired move to Atletico Madrid, Belfast Telegraph Sport understands.\n\nCosta has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\" and insisting he is prepared to remain in exile for a year.\n\nBut it is understood that Chelsea want Costa, a player with two years remaining on his contract, to return to the club.\n\nThe Blues also expect the Brazil-born Spain striker to prove his fitness and make himself available for selection.\n\nAfter being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his anticipated arrival as he agitates for a return to Atletico.\n\nCosta, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe said: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them.\"\n\nChelsea do not have a reserve team, only age-group sides, and Costa has been given no indication he would be expected to train with them, Belfast Telegraph Sport understands.\n\nCosta joined Chelsea from Atletico in July 2014 and has twice won the Premier League title.\n\nHe has scored 59 goals - 52 in the Premier League - across 120 appearances for the Blues.\n\nThe 28-year-old claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments and Conte has recently been reluctant to discuss the player.\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday, the full opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nCosta only wants to move to Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo and cannot register new players until January.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I have rejected other offers,\" he said. \"If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nThe striker said he was happy at Stamford Bridge until Conte made it clear he had no future.\n\nThe friction can be traced to January, when Costa missed the Premier League trip to Leicester after a rumoured behind-the-scenes row with Conte and his coaching staff following speculation over a mega-money move to China.\n\nConte publicly stated Costa's absence was due to a back injury, but the player has now admitted it was for disciplinary reasons.\n\n\"That was a punishment for the attitude I had shown and behaving in the best way,\" he said.\n\nCosta also says he was nearing a new contract with Chelsea at the time, but believes Conte put a halt to negotiations.\n\nCosta was critical of Conte, saying the former Juventus and Italy boss \"doesn't possess charisma\" and expressing anger over the Italian's communication.\n\nHe added: \"There are ways of going about it. He has his own opinion and that will not change.\n\n\"I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nIn June, Costa said Conte sent him a text telling him he would not be part of the squad for next season.\n\n\"I have not deleted the message,\" he added. \"If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go,\" Costa said in an interview published in Monday's Daily Mail.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. But as a person -- no,\" said Costa, who was speaking in his hometown of Lagarto in northeastern Brazil.\n\n\"He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant.
