{"timeCrawl": "12:18:00", "uri": "709211701", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T12:18:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4788912/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa and Chelsea are in dispute over the striker's future. Here Press Association Sport asks some of the most pressing questions about the situation.\n\nWhen did this all start?\n\nWhat a win!!! Great team work and great atmosphere from our fans! Thank you all! #CapitalOneCupFinal pic.twitter.com/8lSh2oFm2j -- Diego Costa (@diegocosta)\n\nMarch 1, 2015\n\nCosta signed for Chelsea from Atletico Madrid for \u00a332million on a five-year contract in July 2014, but there have been continual reports of a move back to the Spanish capital ever since. Hamstring problems plagued his first season but the striker still scored 20 goals in Chelsea's 2014-15 title-winning campaign. There were also on-field disciplinary issues accompanied by retrospective suspensions which led Costa to consider leaving England. Some Chelsea supporters also blamed him for Jose Mourinho's departure in December 2015. He reestablished their faith and scored 20 goals in a second Premier League title success last season.\n\nWhat about his relationship with Antonio Conte?\n\nJose Mourinho signed Costa (Adam Davy/PA)\n\nCosta was integral to Jose Mourinho's Chelsea, leading the forward line with a snarl as arch-antagonist and chief goalscorer. His importance was similar to Conte's Chelsea side last season, with some suggesting the Blues would not have won the title if they had let Costa leave in January. That was when the major fissures occurred as Costa was left out of the team for the win at Leicester following reports of a behind-the-scenes row over a mega-money move to China. Publicly Conte insisted it was because of a back injury.\n\nIf he was so important, why is he surplus to requirements at Chelsea?\n\nCosta kissed the Premier League trophy (Nick Potts/Empics)\n\nConte may have decided Costa was not worth the trouble. The celebrations after the title-clinching win at West Brom in May included Costa, perhaps jokingly, brandishing a fire extinguisher while Conte spoke to a group of journalists. It was a tiny snippet of what it might be like to manage Costa on a daily basis. Plus, if he has agitated for a move, the striker's loyalty may be in question. Costa is also 29 in October, so Conte may want a younger man to lead his team. He has now got Alvaro Morata.\n\nDid Conte make the decision to get rid of Costa?\n\nDiego Costa and Antonio Conte\n\nYes - and this is where there is some dispute. Chelsea and Conte say Costa and his agent, Jorge Mendes, knew in January that the striker would be leaving this summer. Costa claims he was informed by text message in June and has engaged his lawyers. He was expected to return to London in the last two weeks, but remains in exile in Brazil saying Chelsea are fining him for not returning to the club. He is under contract for two more years, but the fact the row has become public - and Costa's determination to rejoin Atletico, rather than go elsewhere - significantly reduces his value.\n\nWhat happens next?\n\nToda honra e toda gl\u00f3ria seja dada a Deus! Parab\u00e9ns rapaziada!!!!! Come on Chelsea!!!\u1f4aa\u1f3fd\u1f499 pic.twitter.com/uLtvPjrLAs -- Diego Costa (@diegocosta)\n\nMay 12, 2017\n\nThere are a number of possible scenarios. Chelsea could agree a deal for Costa to join Atletico, who cannot register new players until January due to a transfer embargo, so they may loan him out elsewhere. With no deal with Atletico agreed, Costa could also remain in Brazil, effectively on strike while the lawyers continue to negotiate. Alternatively, Costa may return to London, training with the Chelsea reserves or on his own, winding down his contract and waiting for a transfer to Atletico. The most unlikely scenario would see a reconciliation with Conte and Chelsea, which would allow for Costa's return.", "id": "9073862", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Q&A: Why has Diego {"timeCrawl": "04:11:00", "uri": "709565609", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T04:11:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/chelsea-keen-for-diego-costa-to-return-to-london-and-prove-his-fitness-36033171.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36033170.ece/8d52a/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-9eff750d-d52a-4562-abc3-846da9c23447_I1.jpg\n\nChelsea want Diego Costa to end his exile, return to London and prove his fitness, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nCosta has criticised Chelsea's treatment of him this summer, saying he is \"not a criminal\", and said he is prepared to remain in exile for a year as he agitates for a return to Atletico Madrid.\n\nBut it is understood that Chelsea want Costa, as a player with two years remaining on his contract, to return to the club.\n\nThe Blues also expect the Brazil-born Spain striker to prove his fitness and make himself available for selection, even though he is no longer in head coach Antonio Conte's plans.\n\nAfter being granted an additional week of leave and missing the pre-season tour to Asia, Costa is still to return to London around two weeks after his anticipated arrival.\n\nCosta, speaking at his family home in Lagarto, Brazil, said he has not reported for training as he does not want to train with the Blues' reserves, and is happy staying in Brazil and paying club fines until his future is resolved.\n\nHe told The Daily Mail: \"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that.\n\n\"I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\"\n\nChelsea do not have a reserve team, only age-group sides, and Costa has been given no indication that he would be expected to train with them, Press Association Sport understands.\n\nCosta joined Chelsea from Atletico in July 2014. He has twice won the Premier League title during his three years at Stamford Bridge and scored 59 goals in 120 appearances.\n\nThe 28-year-old claims he was told he was not wanted by head coach Antonio Conte by text message in the summer and the frontman wishes to return to Atletico.\n\nThe Blues declined to respond to Costa's comments.\n\nChelsea and Conte have previously insisted the decision for Costa to leave this summer was made in January, with both the player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, aware.\n\nCosta only wants to move to Atletico, who are under a transfer embargo and cannot register new players until January.\n\nIn Costa's absence, the Blues lost 3-2 to Burnley on Saturday's opening day of the Premier League season.", "id": "9204879", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-15", "title": "Chelsea keen for Diego Costa to return to London and prove his fitness", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36033170.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-9eff750d-d52a-4562-abc3-846da9c23447_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1673, "date": "2014-07-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 1682}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-15", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [], "time": "04:11:00"}

{"timeCrawl": "12:15:00", "uri": "711430613", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T12:15:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/1437408/diego-costa-blasts-chelsea-for-pricing-him-out-of-dream-return-to-atletico-madrid/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "Exiled striker says: 'Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near' as Brazilian complains about 'tiresome' holiday\n\nDIEGO COSTA has again blasted Chelsea for pricing him out of a dream return to Atletico Madrid.\n\nIn another explosive interview in Brazil, the exiled striker says the Blues are not treating him fairly as they hold out for more money.\n\nHe told ESPN Brazil's Joao Castelo-Branco: \"I've demonstrated I care for Atletico and have interest in playing for them.\n\n\"But if Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me.\n\n\"I know that this [big effort] will happen, but if it's to pay the amount that Chelsea want it won't be possible.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid, so I've given them something back in all senses [sporting and financial].\"\n\nThe Blues paid Atletico \u00a332million for Costa in 2014 - with the striker scoring 59 goals in 120 games for Chelsea, helping them win two Premier League titles and the League Cup in three seasons.\n\nAs SunSport revealed this morning, Atletico Madrid are only willing to pay \u00a330million for the striker - but the Blues want closer to \u00a350m.\n\nWhen asked whether he knew how much Chelsea want for him, Costa replied: \"I don't know, but my agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near.\n\n\"When we heard that [Antonio] Conte didn't want me anymore, my agent went to find out if there was interest from Atletico for me coming back. Of course for the warmth and respect that I earned there, they showed interest.\n\n\"But they wouldn't pay a fortune. Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\"\n\nAfter Costa revealed the text message that led to a breakdown in his relationship with Conte, the pair have barely been on speaking terms.\n\nCosta never returned to training after being told he would have to train away from the first-team, with the reserves.\n\nThe 28-year-old has been training alone in his hometown of Lagarto, Brazil, racking up hefty fines.\n\nCosta claims he has not been told if he may get a chance to return and play for the Blues.\n\n\"I'll be honest, I have my agent and none of that has reached me,\" he added.\n\n\"People at the club called me before [earlier in the summer] to give me extra holidays to not have contact with the manager.\n\n\"I was always meant to turn up with the group, but they were already saying that I'm going to have to come back and train with the reserves.\n\n\"I said that this was a lack of respect. We won the league and I haven't done anything so serious to deserve being treated in that way.\n\n\"It won't be the same as before [between him and Conte], and we don't know if the fight for the position will be fair.\n\n\"Because of me having exposed the [text] message I understand that he'll be annoyed, so if I go back I have to see if things would be clean, just and correct.\n\n\"That's how I like things. If I go back now I don't think it will be a fair situation. It won't be an honest fight for a position [in the team].\"\n\nChelsea want to sell Costa to a Chinese Super League team, knowing he will draw a much higher transfer fee - especially with Atletico unable to play the striker until January because of the transfer ban.\n\nBut Costa again reiterated he only wants a move back to Spain.\n\n\"Chelsea have offered me to several clubs, but I was very clear with them,\" he added.\n\n\"I said that if I'm not part of the manager's plans, I would like to choose my destination.\n\n\"I'm not going to let them decide just to get more money.\n\n\"When I came to Chelsea they paid a lot less compared to what's being offered to them.\n\n\"I think they should take into account everything that I've done. It's not my fault that I'm not at the club.", "id": "9889830", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Bored Diego Costa blasts Chelsea for pricing him out of dream return to Atletico Madrid", {"timeCrawl": "13:25:00", "uri": "709244026", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T13:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"title": "theeagleonline.com.ng", "uri": "theeagleonline.com.ng", "id": "4609"}, "url": "https://theeagleonline.com.ng/chelsea-treating-me-like-a-criminal-costa/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "He has not played for Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May, following which he claims manager Antonio Conte sent him a text, telling him he was not in his plans for the new season.\n\nDiego Costa has accused Chelsea FC of treating him like a \"criminal\", in a forthright newspaper interview which will deepen the breach with the Premier League club.\n\nThe striker is seeking a move back to Spain in the transfer window.\n\nHe has not played for Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May, following which he claims manager Antonio Conte sent him a text, telling him he was not in his plans for the new season.\n\nCosta was interviewed at home in Brazil on the same day Chelsea lost their opening Premier League game to Burnley and said he was refusing the club's demand to return to play with the reserves.\n\nHe said: \"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys.\n\n\"I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\"\n\nThe Brazilian-born Spain international, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in 2014, said if the club did not allow him to move before the transfer window he was prepared to see out his contract unpaid in Brazil.\n\nCosta said: \"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me.\n\n\"I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\n\n\"I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\"\n\nThe situation is complicated by the fact that Atletico are currently banned from signing players in this window although a loan deal would be possible.\n\nCosta's relationship with Conte appears to have broken down although the Brazilian accepts the Italian \"is a good {"timeCrawl": "11:19:00", "uri": "709186140", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:19:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/why-has-diego-costas-relationship-with-chelsea-turned-so-sour-36029912.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36029911.ece/075ee/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-ade775f8-f578-42b4-a9cb-9c172607a991_I1.jpg\n\nDiego Costa and Chelsea are in dispute over the striker's future. Here Press Association Sport asks some of the most pressing questions about the situation.\n\nWhen did this all start?\n\nCosta signed for Chelsea from Atletico Madrid for \u00a332million on a five-year contract in July 2014, but there have been continual reports of a move back to the Spanish capital ever since. Hamstring problems plagued his first season but the striker still scored 20 goals in Chelsea's 2014-15 title-winning campaign. There were also on-field disciplinary issues accompanied by retrospective suspensions which led Costa to consider leaving England. Some Chelsea supporters also blamed him for Jose Mourinho's departure in December 2015. He reestablished their faith and scored 20 goals in a second Premier League title success last season.\n\nWhat about his relationship with Antonio Conte?\n\nCosta was integral to Jose Mourinho's Chelsea, leading the forward line with a snarl as arch-antagonist and chief goalscorer. His importance was similar to Conte's Chelsea side last season, with some suggesting the Blues would not have won the title if they had let Costa leave in January. That was when the major fissures occurred as Costa was left out of the team for the win at Leicester following reports of a behind-the-scenes row over a mega-money move to China. Publicly Conte insisted it was because of a back injury.\n\nIf he was so important, why is he surplus to requirements at Chelsea?\n\nConte may have decided Costa was not worth the trouble. The celebrations after the title-clinching win at West Brom in May included Costa, perhaps jokingly, brandishing a fire extinguisher while Conte spoke to a group of journalists. It was a tiny snippet of what it might be like to manage Costa on a daily basis. Plus, if he has agitated for a move, the striker's loyalty may be in question. Costa is also 29 in October, so Conte may want a younger man to lead his team. He has now got Alvaro Morata.\n\nDid Conte make the decision to get rid of Costa?\n\nYes - and this is where there is some dispute. Chelsea and Conte say Costa and his agent, Jorge Mendes, knew in January that the striker would be leaving this summer. Costa claims he was informed by text message in June and has engaged his lawyers. He was expected to return to London in the last two weeks, but remains in exile in Brazil saying Chelsea are fining him for not returning to the club. He is under contract for two more years, but the fact the row has become public - and Costa's determination to rejoin Atletico, rather than go elsewhere - significantly reduces his value.\n\nWhat happens next?\n\nThere are a number of possible scenarios. Chelsea could agree a deal for Costa to join Atletico, who cannot register new players until January due to a transfer embargo, so they may loan him out elsewhere. With no deal with Atletico agreed, Costa could also remain in Brazil, effectively on strike while the lawyers continue to negotiate. Alternatively, Costa may return to London, training with the Chelsea reserves or on his own, winding down his contract and waiting for a transfer to Atletico. The most unlikely scenario would see a reconciliation with Conte and Chelsea, which would allow for Costa's return.", "id": "9063453", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Why has Diego Costa's relationship with Chelsea turned so sour?", "image": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36029911.ece/ALTERNATES/h342/PANews%20BT_P-ade775f8-f578-42b4-a9cb-9c172607a991_I1.jpg", "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 436, "date": "2014-07-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 445}, {"textStart": 866, "date": "2015-12-", "amb": false, "textEnd": 879}], "dateCrawl": "2017-08-14", "concepts": [], "location": null, "categories": [], "time": "11:19:00"}

The Spain international scored 20 goals last season to fire the Blues to the title but a falling out with the Italian has led to him becoming surplus to requirements in west London.\n\nThe 28-year-old has declared his intent to return to Atletico for a third spell with the club and has urged the Premier League champions to \"set him free\" after Conte informed Costa by text message that he was no longer wanted. Costa has longed for a return to Atletico where he has scored 64 goals in 134 appearances across two spells, guiding the club to the La Liga title and the Champions League final in his last season in 2014.\n\nAtletico, who cannot register Costa until January 2018 due to a transfer embargo imposed by Fifa, have already put together a detailed fitness plan to bring the striker up to speed after he was not involved in Chelsea's pre-season plans, such is their confidence that a deal will be agreed. Atletico.\n\nBut Chelsea have reiterated to the 28-year-old that they expect him to return to England and fulfil the terms of his contract by training and doing everything he can to make himself fit {"timeCrawl": "21:41:00", "uri": "709456569", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T21:41:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"title": "Mail Online", "uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "id": "214"}, "url": "http://www.dailymail.co.uk/~/article-4790392/index.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Chelsea have issued Diego Costa with orders to return to London as soon as possible, train, get match-fit and put himself in contention for the first team.\n\nThis four-point demand is the first hint of a route back into the fold for Costa, even if it locks him on a collision course with manager Antonio Conte.\n\nThe bond between Conte and Costa was broken by the manager's text in June to inform last season's 20-goal top scorer he was not part of his plans.\n\nChelsea have asked Diego Costa to return to London, train and put himself in the frame to play\n\nOver the summer Costa was sent a text by Antonio Conte telling him he was not part of plans\n\nThe forward gave his side of the story when he spoke exclusively to Sportsmail's Adam Crafton\n\nConte claimed the decision was made in January when Costa had been hankering after a move to China and was dropped from the team after a clash with fitness coach Julio Tous. The 28-year-old striker has since decided he would rather return to Atletico Madrid, but the clubs are not close to an agreement.\n\nTalks have stalled and Costa's lawyers want him released on a free transfer because his contract has been breached by Conte's message. For Chelsea, who value the Spain international at more than \u00a360million, losing him for nothing in a legal wrangle is a staggering prospect.\n\nCosta was given permission to report a week late for pre-season training as the club negotiated with Atletico. He was then omitted from a tour of China and Singapore, but hopes of a swift resolution soon disappeared.\n\nCosta is in his home town of Lagarto in Brazil and, in an exclusive Sportsmail interview, published on Sunday, he claimed Chelsea were treating him like a criminal. He vowed to continue training alone in South America rather than report back to work with the reserves in Surrey with no prospect of playing. 'That seems a very bad and ugly life,' said Costa. 'It doesn't respect what I have done for the club.'\n\nCosta has been training alone in Brazil and claimed Chelsea are treating him like a criminal\n\nHe vowed to stay in South America rather work with the reserves with no prospect of playing\n\nChelsea, however, are not prepared to let Costa languish on the other side of the Atlantic when he has two years left on a \u00a3180,000-a-week contract and they are short of players.\n\nThe case of Carlos Tevez and an Italian manager at Manchester City has been mentioned at Stamford Bridge. Tevez was exiled by Roberto Mancini after refusing to come on as a substitute in a Champions League match against Bayern Munich in September 2011.\n\nMancini, furious with the lack of respect shown to his leadership, was adamant that the Argentine had to go, but after a cooling-off period there was an apology and a return to City.\n\nTevez was soon back in the team and the pair survived another season together before both departing in 2013. The idea of having Costa back in Chelsea blue will have huge appeal to fans and some players at Stamford Bridge as he is a popular figure in the dressing room.\n\nCarlos Tevez's exile and return under Roberto Mancini has been mentioned at Stamford Bridge\n\nCosta has been linked with a return to Atletico Madrid to play under manager Diego Simeone\n\nAttempts to coax him back, however, are laced with belated good sense and legal posturing. Chelsea will be keen to make clear Costa has not been denied the chance to do his job as a footballer and there is always a route back into the team. They will also be trying to stir Atletico.\n\nThe transfer window closes two weeks on Thursday but the Spanish club are under no time pressure because they are banned by FIFA from registering any new players until the end of the year.\n\nAtletico, like Costa, are content to play a waiting game but there is logic to ensuring a move is completed before January. At least he could train with Diego Simeone and future team-mates and be closer to Spain manager Julen Lopetegui, who he must impress if he is to play at the World Cup next summer.\n\nExactly what Conte, already bristling at not getting everything his way, will make of a returning Costa is another matter.\n\nThe return of Costa will go down well with some players as he is a popular squad member\n\nThus far, he has refused to discuss the issue in public, other than to say his decision was made in January and that Costa has been aware of the position since then.\n\nWhen Conte texted Costa in June, he was in a position of tremendous personal strength after a magnificent debut season in the Premier League. He had transformed the team, won the title and made it to the FA Cup final.\n\nA new four-year contract was on the table and there was the promise of a major recruitment drive to build a squad capable of challenging in the Champions League. Two months on and Conte's status has been radically altered. Recruitment did not go to plan, top targets escaped and the four-year deal became a two-year deal as tensions increased.\n\nForm in pre-season was poor and the champions started the Premier League campaign with a 3-2 home defeat by Burnley.\n\nConte's side suffered a disappointing start to the league season, losing 3-2 at home to Burnley\n\nChelsea finished the game with nine men, adding to a feeling of disarray with echoes of 2015 when the title defence went awry under Jose Mourinho. Last month, Conte said he feared a repeat of 'the Mourinho season' and could be sacked.\n\nHis reservations about the strength of his squad were compounded by the sale of Nemanja Matic to Manchester United.\n\nWith Roman Abramovich's fondness for change and Conte's propensity to storm off in a huff, focus will sharpen on the manager's position if harmony cannot be restored. He is the book- makers' favourite to be the next manager to leave.\n\nHis contract runs until 2019 -- the same as Costa's -- and while no-one expects the striker to outlast Conte, anything can happen He's earning a fortune at Chelsea. Can Atletico Madrid even afford him?\"\n\nCosta, who last played for Chelsea in the FA Cup final in May, joined the Blues from Atletico Madrid in 2014 and has won two Premier League titles and the League Cup with the London club.\n\nIn January, he was left out of the side for an away match at Leicester after he was involved in a dispute with a fitness coach.\n\nIt followed reports of an offer from China that would have been worth \u00a330m a year in salary.\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me?\" he told the Daily Mail on Monday.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change.\"\n\n\"Antonio Conte has told me by message that I do not follow at Chelsea and that's it. Conte said he did not count on me for next season,\" said Costa in June.\n\nThat came after the Italian manager had sent a text to his players wishing them a good holiday and telling them to stay fit and Costa replied in a jokey way.\n\nBut Wright says he cannot understand why Chelsea would want to get rid of a forward who scored 20 goals in 35 Premier League games to help the Blues win the Premier League last season.\n\n\"Something has happened,\" added Wright, who played 33 times for England.\n\n\"For them to want to get rid of that kind of player, I can't understand how that's come about. I can't understand why you would get rid of definitely 20 goals? It doesn't make sense to me.\"\n\nFollowing the text message exchange with Conte, Costa said \"I love to live in Madrid\", despite Atletico being banned from signing players until the January transfer window.\n\n\"Why does it seem he is holding all the cards? He genuinely wants to go, but only wants to go to Atletico Madrid,\" added Wright.\n\n\"If Chelsea want to get rid of him and get bids for a player they don't want, they're not going to take them?\n\n\"I would like to see the text. Show us the text. Then I don't blame him, because I would have the hump over that.\"\n\nCosta said: \"I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop.\"\n\nFormer Chelsea and Republic of Ireland midfielder Andy Townsend says Conte telling Costa he is not wanted at the club is like Manchester United, Arsenal and Tottenham telling their star forwards not to return.\n\n\"Something else is going on,\" he said. \"There's no logic from Chelsea's point of view to get rid of him.\n\n\"You don't send him a text and say 'off you pop, we don't want you to come back'. They don't do that. They don't just turn round with one of their main components and say 'go and find a new club'.\n\n\"It's like Jose Mourinho saying to Zlatan Ibrahimovic before he was injured, Arsene Wenger saying to Alexis Sanchez, Tottenham saying to Harry Kane 'don't come back'. {"timeCrawl": "10:47:00", "uri": "709172212", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T10:47:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/timeline-of-events-leading-up-to-diego-costas-chelsea-exile-36029790.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36029789.ece/ce928/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-682fc4ab-fe0e-430a-8069-f1870ec408c1_I1.jpg\n\nStriker Diego Costa is in dispute with Chelsea. The 28-year-old moved from Atletico Madrid for \u00a332million in July 2014, signing a five-year contract, and has won two Premier League titles and the League Cup in three seasons at Stamford Bridge.\n\nHere, Press Association Sport provides a timeline of the events which have led to his exile.\n\n:: January 13\n\nCosta does not travel with the Chelsea squad to Leicester for the following day's fixture following reports of a behind-the-scenes bust-up with Antonio Conte and his backroom staff amid suggestions the striker's head had been turned by a mega-money offer from China.\n\n:: January 14\n\nWithout Costa, Chelsea win 3-0 at Leicester. Conte insists the reason for the striker's omission was a back injury, saying: \"I like to tell the truth, and that is Diego stopped training on Tuesday. He didn't train in the week because he wasn't fit.\"\n\n:: January 16\n\nCosta trains on his own for a second successive day after missing the Leicester match, while his first-team colleagues enjoyed two days off.\n\n:: January 17\n\nThe owner of Tianjin Quanjian, who had been linked with a mega-money offer for Costa, says new rules in the Chinese Super League have altered their recruitment plans. But speculation gathers of a return to Atletico Madrid.\n\n:: January 20\n\nConte says Costa is available to play against Hull. The Italian adds: \"I think the player wants to stay at Chelsea. He's very happy to play with us. This idea (to move) is far from his mind. I'm sure about his commitment, his behaviours, his will to fight with this team, to try together to fight to the end to try to win the title.\"\n\n:: January 22\n\nCosta is restored to Chelsea's starting line-up at the first opportunity and scores his 52nd goal on his 100th Chelsea appearance in a 2-0 win over Hull. Conte says: \"I hope with this game to finish the speculation about him, about Chelsea, about me and him. We showed we are a team with great unity.\"\n\n:: January 31\n\nCosta has a penalty saved in a 1-1 Premier League draw at rivals Liverpool, on transfer deadline day.\n\n:: February 3\n\nWith the Chinese Super League transfer window still open and thoughts in Europe turning to the summer, speculation continues to swirl around Costa. Conte says: \"Every week I hear a lot of news, a lot of speculation about Diego. I think now the most important thing is to be focused on this championship.\"\n\n:: February 17\n\nConte says the future of all his players, including Costa, will be discussed at the end of the season as the focus should not waver from winning the Premier League title.\n\n:: May 8\n\nCosta scores his 20th goal of the Premier League season in a 3-0 win over Middlesbrough which takes the Blues within reach of the Premier League title.\n\n:: May 27\n\nChelsea lose the FA Cup final 2-1 to Arsenal. Costa scores his 59th goal for the Blues on his 120th appearance.\n\n:: May 28\n\nCosta insists he does not wish to move to China and only wants to move to Atletico if he leaves Chelsea. \"I have no intention of leaving, I'm very happy here, I have two years on my contract, but if the club want to sell me there is one club I would go to,\" Costa says.\n\n:: June 8\n\nCosta says Conte sent him a text message to tell the striker he is not in his plans next season.\n\n:: July 21\n\nOn Chelsea's pre-season tour to Asia, without Costa, Conte says the decision to cut the striker from his squad was made in January. The player and his agent, Jorge Mendes, were aware. \"The situation is closed,\" Conte adds.\n\n:: August 4\n\nA lawyer stating he represents Costa threatens legal action after the striker was told he was free to leave. Chelsea describe claims Conte is forcing out Costa as \"just nonsense\".\n\n:: August 11\n\nChelsea and Conte are tight-lipped on Costa as it emerges legal proceedings are taking place behind the scenes.\n\n:: August 14\n\nCosta criticises Chelsea's treatment of him this summer in an interview with The Daily Mail. They believe Chelsea are blocking the Spanish/Brazilian's move back to his beloved Atletico Madrid.\n\nCosta hinted at a desire to move to China during last January's transfer window. It was something that didn't go down well in London with Antonio Conte.\n\nConte has since claimed that Costa and his agent were told that the striker would not be part of his plans for the season that has just begun. Whether a text was sent in the summer outlining this we don't know. They say he faces a two week wage fine, believed to be in the region of \u00a3300,000. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it.\n\nTOO FAT: Chelsea fear no one will want to buy Costa\n\n\"I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no.\n\n\"I was with the Spain national team, alone in my room, when it (the text message) came through. It was a shock to get it like that. I was showing it to my team-mates and they could not believe how he had done it. I was angry at the time. Now I am more calm.\n\n\"I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop. Conte has his mentality. He thinks it's the best way of working.\n\n\"My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, \"If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid\". I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams.\n\n\"If I have to I will stay in Brazil. I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. {"timeCrawl": "07:50:00", "uri": "709097905", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T07:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"title": "International Business Times UK", "uri": "ibtimes.co.uk", "id": "713"}, "url": "http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/i-am-waiting-chelsea-set-me-free-says-diego-costa-he-pushes-atletico-madrid-move-1634872", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "The Brazilian-born striker adds he has rejected offers from China in hopes of returning to Madrid.\n\nExiled Chelsea forward has given a detailed assessment of his current situation as he looks to leave the club and return to Atletico Madrid.\n\nCosta last appeared for the Blues in a losing effort after a 2-1 defeat to Arsenal in the FA Cup final back in May where he scored the equalizer before Aaron Ramsey's winner.\n\nSince then, Costa has been in no man's land, having yet to appear in a single pre-season game after manager Antonio Conte informed him via text message that his future at the club was over.\n\nThe 28-year-old has since been linked with a return to former club Atletico Madrid while AC Milan have also shown an interest in the forward.\n\nHowever, with just over two weeks of the transfer window to go, Costa's future is still uncertain but he does not expect to remain at Stamford Bridge either.\n\n\"No,\" Costa told the Daily Mail when asked if he expects Conte to call for his return. \"You know that the manager doesn't want me.\"\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. I cannot speak for other people, only for myself. I had a great season. I fought in every game until the last moment.\"\n\nThe problems started in January when Costa was involved in a training ground row with fitness coach Julio Tous, with rumours of a move to China emerging soon afterwards, right when the Spain international was ready to renew his contract.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach,\" he explained. \"I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\"\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\nCosta adds that the club have been forcing him to train with the reserves like a \"criminal\" to which the Lagarto native has already defied Chelsea, resulting in fines. If he cannot leave Chelsea, he also claims he will stay in Brazil for a year and train.\n\nHowever, Costa is also ready to go through the legal routes with his lawyer in order to force a move back to Atletico Madrid where he played until 2014.\n\n'At the moment, no [legal proceedings have begun],\" he added. \"I want people to do things the right way. Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\"\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid'.\n\n\"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone (Atletico manager) wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. from Brazil, where he has been AWOL for the past four weeks, to return to training at Chelsea but has insisted he will not return.\n\nThe 28-year-old has made no secret of his desire to return to the Spanish capital with Atletico, where he won the 2014 La Liga title, but as of yet an agreement between the two clubs is not imminent.\n\nAnd Costa has claimed that Chelsea, whose manager Antonio Conte told the striker in a text earlier this summer that he was no longer part of the Blues' plans, are setting too high a price for his services.\n\n\"I've demonstrated I care for Atletico and have interest in playing for them,\" he told ESPN Brasil. \"But if Atletico and Chelsea don't come to an agreement and Atletico don't make a big effort, I can't keep on wanting to play for a club that isn't going to make a bigger effort to try and sign me.\n\n\"I know that this will happen, but if it's to pay the amount that Chelsea want it won't be possible.\"\n\nStandard Sport has reported that Atletico have only offered \u00a326million whilst Chelsea are demanding around \u00a350m.\n\nHowever Costa has claimed that Chelsea could still make a profit from his services if they are willing to negotiate with Atleti, who would be unable to register him as a new player until January due to the transfer ban they are currently serving.\n\n\"What I know is that this offer Chelsea will get is bigger than what they paid [\u00a332million in the summer of 2014], so I've given them something back in all senses.\n\n\"I don't know [how much the Blues want], but my agent said that Chelsea want something that Atletico can't get near.\n\n\"When we heard that Conte didn't want me anymore, my agent went to find out if there was interest from Atletico for me coming back. Of course for the warmth and respect that I earned there, they showed interest. But they wouldn't pay a fortune. Atletico is a team growing every year, a big team, but they can't pay an extraordinary amount.\"\n\nAC Milan have entered the race to sign Costa and, having been taken over by Chinese investors in April, have the financial muscle to come closer to Chelsea's asking price.\n\nHowever the Spain international is insistent that he will only go to Atletico.\n\n\"Chelsea have offered me to several clubs, but I was very clear with them,\" he said. \"I said that if I'm not part of the manager's plans, I would like to choose my destination.\n\n\"I'm not going to let them decide just to get more money.\"", "id": "9879646", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-18", "title": "Diego Costa accuses Chelsea of pricing him out of Atletico return", "image": "https://www.standard.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2017/08/02/07/diegocosta0208abc.jpg", "extractedDates": null, "dateCrawl": "2017-08-18", "concepts": [{"location": {"label": {"eng": "Brazil"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 4, "id": "30", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brazil", "label": {"eng": "Brazil"}, "type": "loc"}, {"location": {"label": {"eng": "Spain"}, "type": "country"}, "score": 1, "id": "67", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spain", "label": {"eng": "Spain"}, "type": "loc"}, {"label": {"eng": "Spanish language"}, "id": "303577", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spanish_language"}, {"label": {"eng": "Chelsea F.C."}, "id": "304434", "score": 5, "type": "org", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chelsea_F.C."}, {"label": {"eng": "La Liga"}, "id": "305674", "score": 3, "type": "wiki", "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Liga"}, {"label": {"eng": "A.C. But the Spain international says he wants to move to Atletico Madrid and not to China as he believes Chelsea want. The problem for Costa is that Atletico are banned from signing any new players until January 2018.\n\n\"What is happening now with Chelsea is sad,\" Costa told the Daily Mail.\n\n\"The text message -- I understand it when a coach wants a different player. Alvaro Morata is a great player. He had a great season in Madrid and actually with the way this crazy transfer market is, I think they got a good price for a young and talented forward. He will triumph at Chelsea, but there are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. You should be honest and direct to someone's face.\n\n\"I was with the Spain national team, alone in my room, when it came through. It was a shock to get it like that. I was showing it to my team-mates and they could not believe how he had done it.\n\n\"I was angry at the time. Now I am more calm. I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop.\"\n\nHe added: \"Conte has his mentality. He thinks it's the best way of working.\n\n\"He arrived from an Italian league where everyone is very serious and arrived in a dressing room where there are maybe more jokes.\n\n\"The worst bit of all this, it is for the fans. They have always treated me so well -- always, always. For this, I am sad. I hope they understand things happen in football.\n\n\"Conte is a great coach. He deserves to be where he is but it's his opinion. He has his reasons.\"\n\nCosta is ready to make legal moves to force through a move away from the club although proceedings have yet to commence but he wants to return to Atletico where he played from 2010 to 2014.\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, \"If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.\n\n\"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\nFinally, he said: \"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\n...\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying \"I miss you\" and that they love me.\n\n\"I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico [Madrid]. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.' I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me. I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live.\"\n\n18 days remain in the summer transfer window in Spain. {"timeCrawl": "08:38:00", "uri": "710202671", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T08:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"title": "Sportslens.com", "uri": "sportslens.com", "id": "17610"}, "url": "http://sportslens.com/former-manchester-united-defender-says-diego-costa-will-rejoin-atletico/214575/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Terry Gibson believes it is inevitable that Chelsea striker Diego Costa will rejoin Atletico Madrid.\n\nCosta is currently back home in Brazil and has threatened to stay there rather than return to London, and then leave on a free transfer.\n\nChelsea have ordered the player to return to the club and put himself in contention for selection. However, Gibson believes the Premier League champions have handled the situation badly.\n\n\"It has really depreciated his value in a market this summer where they could have got an absolute fortune for Diego Costa,\" he told Sky Sports.\n\n\"The way it was done in terms of the alleged text message between Antonio Conte and Costa devalues the player's worth, and that was devalued even more by the {"timeCrawl": "19:34:00", "uri": "709409018", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:34:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"title": "BBC News", "uri": "bbc.co.uk", "id": "264"}, "url": "http://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40930296", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Chelsea forward Diego Costa's refusal to return to training is \"disgraceful\", says former Arsenal striker Ian Wright.\n\nThe 28-year-old, who is currently in his native Brazil, said he has been treated like a \"criminal\" and wants to join former club Atletico Madrid.\n\nChelsea boss Antonio Conte texted Costa in June to say he was not in his plans, but Costa says he has been told to return and train with the reserves.\n\n\"I don't understand how players can get away with that behaviour,\" said Wright.\n\nSpain striker Costa was given extra time off by Chelsea last month, but now claims he is being fined for his absence and is considering legal action or seeing out the remaining year of his contract unpaid in Brazil.\n\n\"It's disgraceful the way he is behaving,\" Wright told BBC Radio 5 live's The Monday Night Club.\n\n\"Surely he's got to come back here, so if the manager changes his mind he's there. He's earning a fortune at Chelsea. Can Atletico Madrid even afford him?\"\n\nCosta, who last played for Chelsea in the FA Cup final in May, joined the Blues from Atletico Madrid in 2014 and has won two Premier League titles and the League Cup with the London club.\n\nIn January, he was left out of the side for an away match at Leicester after he was involved in a dispute with a fitness coach.\n\nIt followed reports of an offer from China that would have been worth \u00a330m a year in salary.\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me?\" he told the Daily Mail on Monday.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change.\"\n\n\"Antonio Conte has told me by message that I do not follow at Chelsea and that's it. Conte said he did not count on me for next season,\" said Costa in June.\n\nThat came after the Italian manager had sent a text to his players wishing them a good holiday and telling them to stay fit and Costa replied in a jokey way.\n\nBut Wright says he cannot understand why Chelsea would want to get rid of a forward who scored 20 goals in 35 Premier League games to help the Blues win the Premier League last season.\n\n\"Something has happened,\" added Wright, who played 33 times for England.\n\n\"For them to want to get rid of that kind of player, I can't understand how that's come about. I can't understand why you would get rid of definitely 20 goals? It doesn't make sense to me.\"\n\nFollowing the text message exchange with Conte, Costa said \"I love to live in Madrid\", despite Atletico being banned from signing players until the January transfer window.\n\n\"Why does it seem he is holding all the cards? He genuinely wants to go, but only wants to go to Atletico Madrid,\" added Wright.\n\n\"If Chelsea want to get rid of him and get bids for a player they don't want, they're not going to take them?\n\n\"I would like to see the text. Show us the text. Then I don't blame him, because I would have the hump over that.\"\n\nCosta said: \"I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. {"timeCrawl": "10:56:00", "uri": "711397441", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T10:56:00Z", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "source": {"title": "Footynad.net", "uri": "footymad.net", "id": "5396"}, "url": "http://www.footymad.net/diego-costa-not-backing-down-over-his-wish-to-swap-chelsea-f/9035440/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "Exiled striker Diego Costa has repeated his wish to return to Atletico Madrid and believes his stand-off with Chelsea will come to an end when he travels to Spain.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain international signed for \u00a332million from Atletico in July 2014, agreeing a five-year contract, and wishes to return to the Spanish capital.\n\nSpeaking from his native Lagarto earlier this week, Costa criticised Chelsea and head coach Antonio Conte.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by a text message sent by Conte during the off-season.\n\nBut the Blues insist it was decided in January, with the striker and his agent, Jorge Mendes, that Costa could leave this summer.\n\nAs a consequence, Costa has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection, as he still has two years remaining on his contract.\n\nCosta met with Milton Dantas, the president of the Sergipe Football Association, and afterwards reiterated his desire to return to Atletico. Sergipe is the region of Brazil where Costa is from.\n\nIn a statement released by Federacao Sergipana de Futebol and published by O Globo, Costa said: \"My destiny is already set.\n\n\"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season.\n\n\"There happens to be an impasse as Chelsea do not want to release me.\n\n\"But I believe this situation will be resolved upon my return to Spain.\"\n\nHe did not say when he would be returning to Spain, but his preferred move is complicated by Atletico's transfer embargo, which forbids them from registering new players until January.\n\nThe statement from the Sergipe FA is the first sign that Costa is prepared to use official channels to negotiate his departure from Stamford Bridge.\n\nPress Association Sport understands Costa has not yet contacted FIFA, football's world governing body, over his concerns.\n\nAnd FIFPro, the global players' union, is yet to by contacted by Costa.\n\nBut FIFPro has general concerns about the trade of players through transfers.\n\nA FIFPro statement said: \"We strongly believe that players at every level of the football pyramid should have the same right as workers in other industries to follow the career path of their choice.\n\n\"A footballer's career should not be tied to a transfer market which has spiraled out of control.\n\n\"FIFPro is not in a position to comment on the specifics of the situation of either Diego Costa.\n\n\"However, we are aware of repeated instances of the financial interests of clubs interfering with the short career of players.\n\n\"Indeed, FIFPro's recent global survey of {"timeCrawl": "10:41:00", "uri": "710826464", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/english-soccer/diego-costa-refuses-to-return-to-london-and-wants-atleti-move-1.3189472", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "The 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain international signed for \u00a332million from Atletico in July 2014, agreeing a five-year contract, and wishes to return to the Spanish capital.\n\nSpeaking from his native Lagarto earlier this week, Costa criticised Chelsea and head coach Antonio Conte.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by a text message sent by Conte during the off-season.\n\nBut the Blues insist it was decided in January, with the striker and his agent, Jorge Mendes, that Costa could leave this summer.\n\nAs a consequence, Costa has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection, as he still has two years remaining on his contract.\n\nCosta met with Milton Dantas, the president of the Sergipe Football Association, and afterwards reiterated his desire to return to Atletico. Sergipe is the region of Brazil where Costa is from.\n\nIn a statement released by Federacao Sergipana de Futebol and published by O Globo, Costa said: \"My destiny is already set.\n\n\"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season. There happens to be an impasse as Chelsea do not want to release me.\n\n\"But I believe this situation will be resolved upon my return to Spain.\"\n\nHe did not say when he would be returning to Spain, but his preferred move is complicated by Atletico's transfer embargo, which forbids them from registering new players until January.\n\nThe statement from the Sergipe FA is the first sign that Costa is prepared to use official channels to negotiate his departure from Stamford Bridge.\n\nAccording to reports, Costa has not yet contacted Fifa, football's world governing body, over his concerns.\n\nAnd Fifpro, the global players' union, is yet to by contacted by Costa.\n\nBut Fifpro has general concerns about the trade of players through transfers.\n\nA Fifpro statement said: \"We strongly believe that players at every level of the football pyramid should have the same right as workers in other industries to follow the career path of their choice.\n\n\"A footballer's career should not be tied to a transfer market which has spiraled out of control.\n\n\"Fifpro is not in a position to comment on the specifics of the situation of either Diego Costa.\n\n\"However, we are aware of repeated instances of the financial interests of clubs interfering with the short career of players.\n\n\"Indeed, Fifpro's recent global survey of professional players found that 29 per cent I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\n...\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying \"I miss you\" and that they love me.\n\n\"I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico [Madrid]. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.' I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me. I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live.\"\n\n18 days remain in the summer transfer window in Spain. "telegraph.co.uk", "id": "220"}, "url": "http://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2017/08/16/diego-costa-could-face-legal-action-chelsea-doesnt-return-training/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa could face the threat of being sued by Chelsea if he ignores the club's requests to return to training.\n\nAnd the saga could yet extend past the end of this month, as Atletico Madrid can sign Costa after the transfer window has closed on the understanding he would not be able to play until January.\n\nChelsea have once again ordered Costa back from Brazil, where he has spent the entire summer hoping that a return to Atletico Madrid will be agreed.\n\nAtletico's transfer embargo that runs until January has complicated the matter, although the Spanish club can sign Costa after the window has closed on the agreement he cannot be registered to play until the New Year.\n\nFIFA will allow clubs to sign a contract with a player in or outside a transfer window, as long as the rest of their regulations are adhered to.\n\nDeportivo La Coruna and Real Betis are the latest clubs to indicate they would be willing to Costa on loan until January, but the striker has so far rejected the idea of a temporary move before re-joining Atletico.\n\nCosta revealed that he has been fined for failing to return to Chelsea since receiving Antonio Conte's text message informing him he was not part of his plans for this season.\n\nTalking tactics: Do Chelsea have a Plan B? 01:50\n\nIn an interview this week, Costa claimed he was prepared to stay in Brazil and keep being fined for the entire season if Chelsea do not agree a deal to sell him to Atletico.\n\nCosta's lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, has also warned that he \"will use all possible legal mechanisms\" to allow his client to leave Stamford Bridge.\n\nChelsea dismissed Cardoso's claim that Costa has been forced out by text message as \"nonsense\", insisting the player and his advisors were told in January that he would be able to find a new team this summer\n\nChelsea say that any legal consequences of Costa's situation are hypothetical and remain adamant that he must return to training and work to make himself available for selection.\n\nShould he fail to do so, however, Costa and his representatives could face the threat of being sued for effectively wiping millions of pounds off his valuation.\n\nAtletico have so far refused to meet Chelsea's asking price for Costa, with the Spanish club also reluctant to pay his full \u00a3150,000-a-week wages until January, and his value will only diminish further the longer he remains in Brazil.\n\nChelsea are adamant they will not let Costa go for a knockdown fee, but, in theory, the club could investigate trying to sue the player and his advisors for the difference between his sale price and market value if it was felt he eventually left at a reduced price.\n\nThe Premier League champions are not currently looking at taking any legal action of their own and parallels have been drawn between the Costa case and Carlos Tevez going on strike in 2011 while he was a Manchester City player.\n\nTevez was reintegrated into the City squad after spending more than three months on strike in Argentina, during which time legal action was threatened from both sides.\n\nThe striker considered trying to sue then City manager Roberto Mancini, while City looked at the possibility of claiming compensation against Tevez for the reduction in his value.\n\nTevez eventually returned to City, apologised and remained at the club for over a year before joining Juventus where Conte was then manager.\n\nMeanwhile, Leicester City are ready to tell Chelsea that they will have to hand over the Nemanja Matic money to land Danny Drinkwater in the final weeks of the transfer window.\n\nChelsea will make a second offer of around \u00a325million for Drinkwater after having an initial \u00a315m bid rejected by the Foxes.\n\nDrinkwater is interested in a move to Stamford Bridge, but Leicester value the \u00a327-year-old at \u00a340m - the same fee Chelsea received for Matic from Manchester United.\n\nConte is desperate for new signings to be made following Chelsea's opening day defeat to Burnley. But Southampton remain insistent that central defender Virgil van Dijk is not for sale and sources close to Alex Sandro do not expect Juventus to sell the left-back at this stage of the transfer {"timeCrawl": "11:27:00", "uri": "709189216", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:27:00Z", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "source": {"title": "Sky Sports", "uri": "skysports.com", "id": "709"}, "url": "http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10988267/diego-costas-situation-is-a-problem-for-chelsea-says-jimmy-floyd-hasselbaink", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa's situation is a problem for Chelsea, says Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink By Dev Trehan\n\nLast Updated: 14/08/17 12:19pm\n\nFormer Chelsea striker Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink has called for a speedy resolution over Diego Costa's future.\n\nChelsea boss Antonio Conte reportedly texted Costa in June informing the striker he was not part of his future plans, and the striker has since remained in his native Brazil.\n\nThe 28-year-old's lawyer, Ricardo Cardoso, said last week his client intended to hand in a formal transfer request and is considering legal action against Chelsea in order to force through a move to former club Atletico Madrid.\n\nCosta has since indicated he is prepared to remain in Brazil for an entire year without playing if needs be, and Hasselbaink says the time has come for everyone to draw a line under the matter.\n\n\"It's a difficult situation,\" Hasselbaink told Premier League Daily on Sky Sports News.\n\n\"Obviously he had a brilliant season last year [where he scored 20 league goals to help fire Chelsea to the Premier League title].\n\n\"Whatever the reasons are, Conte has made the decision that he wants to go in a different direction and that is his prerogative. The Costa problem does not help and there needs to be a solution ASAP because Chelsea need to move on.\"\n\nTony Cottee was also in the studio for Premier League Daily and the former England striker questioned Conte's handling of the Costa situation, adding Chelsea must replace the Brazil-born Spain international with someone who wants to play for the club.\n\n\"All these issues with Costa. He's sunbathing in Brazil. It's crazy,\" Cottee said.\n\n\"I think the mistake was the so-called text that he [Conte] has apparently sent to him. I think that is where the issue is. I know if I was Diego Costa and I received a text from my manager I would not be very happy about it.\n\n\"What's wrong with calling the player in and sitting down man-to-man and thrashing it out. If you want the player to move on, tell him to his face. It's obviously upset Costa, and Costa is now doing what he is doing, which is the normal process for players that are unhappy - they disappear and everything else.\n\n\"He's their best striker and he's on holiday in Brazil. Like Jimmy says, if he is not going to play just get rid of him. Sell him, get rid of him and move on.\n\n\"The bottom line is if you have an unhappy player at your football club you have to move them on. Do whatever you have got to do to move him on and get the money in and spend it on a player that wants to play.\"\n\nCosta has his heart set on a return to Atletico Madrid and Sky Sports' Spanish football expert Guillem Balague says the current situation suits the Spanish club perfectly.\n\n\"It feels quite clear that he's got one plan. That plan is to go to Atletico Madrid,\" Balague said.\n\n\"Atletico have told him for a while to sit tight and that the longer you sit the cheaper you will be but I'm not sure that's something Chelsea will want to deal with.\n\n\"They say there's a price for him and Atletico are saying sit tight. He should be here with a big smile on his face every day,\" the former Blues midfielder told The Debate.\n\n\"Conte looks like the type of man that thinks 'if you get in the way of what I really want to do every day, you are going to bug me and annoy me'. And I'd be knocking on the owner's door asking him to take the problem away.\n\n\"But sitting in Brazil, he's not a problem to Conte. All of this bravado from the other side of the world isn't getting him anywhere quick. Do your work, do your training, pick your wages up, appear to be a good pro on the face of it and be ready for selection but you can make it loud and clear in other ways that your time is done.\n\n\"The communication here has got so lost along the line. To be champions one minute and when there is a dearth of fantastic No 9's around the world, he is one of them. As an asset, Chelsea are losing millions on this guy. It defies any logic really.\"\n\nHis sentiments were echoed by former striker Wright, who says Costa has shown 'terrible professionalism' by choosing to stay in Brazil and should go about the situation in a different way.\n\n\"He should be back at Chelsea training. It says in his contract that you have to be there fit and ready if selected whatever happens,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't know if somewhere along the line, that's gone out of the window with players because as soon as they don't want to be there, they go on strike. He's still in Brazil and the season has started and he's not fit. decision to exile Diego Costa is threatening to damage his strong bonds with other Chelsea players.\n\nCosta is a popular figure in the dressing room and remains in regular contact with close friends Willian, David Luiz and Spain team-mates including Cesc Fabregas.\n\nSome fear they could be the next to be discarded in brutal fashion by title-winning manager Conte amid off-field tensions and an awful start to the new campaign.\n\nAntonio Conte exiled Diego Costa this summer, telling the forward he was not part of his plans\n\nThe Chelsea star has been in Brazil but the club want him to return to train and get match-fit\n\nCosta is popular among the Chelsea players and remains in contact with the likes of Willian\n\nChelsea have ordered Costa, who has two years left on a \u00a3180,000-a-week contract, to return to the club from Brazil, train, get match-fit and put himself in contention for first-team selection.\n\nIt is the first hint of a route back into Conte's team for the 28-year-old striker who was told in a text from the manager in June that he was no longer in his plans.\n\nCosta was given permission to report a week late for pre-season training in the hope a transfer deal might be struck with Atletico Madrid, the only club he said he was prepared to sign for.\n\nHe was expected back in mid-July and has been informed by the club that he must report for training but he is yet to return.\n\nIn an exclusive interview with Sportsmail from Brazil, Costa said he was prepared to continue training in his hometown Lagarto and will accept club fines rather than return to Chelsea and train with the reserves.\n\nCosta told Sportsmail he will accept club fines rather than return and train with the reserves\n\nThe forward claimed that although the Chelsea boss was a 'great coach', he lacked 'charisma'\n\nHe also said Conte was a 'great coach' but lacked 'charisma' and was used to working in Italian football 'where everyone is very serious'.\n\nA difficult pre-season for Chelsea was compounded by a 3-2 defeat at home by Burnley on Saturday. Gary Cahill and Fabregas were sent off and Conte criticised their discipline.\n\nChelsea have collected four red cards in their last three official games. Cahill and Fabregas are now banned for the Premier League match against Tottenham at Wembley on Sunday, heaping pressure on a small squad. "eng-3368442", "body": "London, Aug 17 (IANS) Chelsea's Spanish forward Diego Costa on Thursday confirmed his intention to return to Spanish football giants Atletico Madrid during the current summer transfer window.\n\nThe 28-year-old Spain international had fallen out of favour with Chelsea's Italian coach, Antonio Conte, who reportedly asked him at the end of last season via a text message to search for another club, reports Efe.\n\n\"My destination is already made,\" Costa said in a statement. \"I must return to Atletico Madrid.\"\n\n\"It turns out that there is the impasse that Chelsea does not want to release me,\" Costa added. \"But I believe that this situation will be resolved now on my return to Spain.\"\n\nThe Brazilian-born forward has been in Brazil since last season ended, but the English Premier League's defending champions have expressed their wish to have him join their current training sessions.\n\nCosta's attorney, Ricardo Cardoso, confirmed last week his client's intention to present a transfer request to the Blues.\n\nCardoso did not rule out taking legal action against Chelsea to ensure his departure from Stamford Bridge.\n\nChelsea, who paid 32 million pounds ($41.2 million) to sign Costa in 2014 from Atletico, seeks a 50-million pound (around $64 million) bid to let him leave, which is 26 million pounds ($33 million) more than what the La Liga side is offering.\n\nIf a deal were to be finally reached, Costa would not be able to play with Atletico during the first half of the season due to FIFA's ban that prevents the Spanish club from I must return to Atletico Madrid. It turns out that there is the impasse that Chelsea does not want to release me. But I believe that this situation will be resolved now on my return to Spain.\"\n\nCosta has never made a secret of his desire to rejoin Atletico, the club with whom he won both a La Liga title and the Copa del Rey in addition to reaching the Champions League final in a successful second stint with Los Colchoneros that lasted between 2010 and 2014.\n\nAtletico are said to be interested in securing the return of the Spain international, despite a transfer ban upheld by the Court of Arbitration for Sport (Cas) that would leave them unable to register him until January 2018. physical plan to help him maintain fitness until he is able to play in the New Year.\n\nDiego Simeone could also contemplate sanctioning a short-term loan deal, with the player having previously Overnight the next episode has been released. The Brazilian born Spanish international has given an exclusive interview to The Daily Mail. Crafton had arrived unannounced but Costa let him in.\n\n\"It's going well for Chelsea, isn't it? The red card changed the game but anyway, you've come a long way and I have nothing to hide. Come on in.\"\n\nCosta has a lot to say. In the article he speaks about everything that has gone on. Sergipe is the region of Brazil where Costa is from.\n\nIn a statement released by Federacao Sergipana de Futebol and published by O Globo, Costa said: \"My destiny is already set.\n\n\"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season.\n\n\"There happens to be an impasse as Chelsea do not want to release me.\n\n\"But I believe this situation will be resolved upon my return to Spain.\"\n\nHe did not say when he would be returning to Spain, but his preferred move is complicated by Atletico's transfer embargo, which forbids them from registering new players until January.\n\nThe statement from the Sergipe FA is the first sign that Costa is prepared to use official channels to negotiate his departure from Stamford Bridge.\n\nPress Association Sport understands Costa has not yet contacted FIFA, football's world governing body, over his concerns.\n\nAnd FIFPro, the global players' union, is yet to by contacted by Costa.\n\nBut FIFPro has general concerns about the trade of players through transfers.\n\nA FIFPro statement said: \"We strongly believe that players at every level of the football pyramid should have the same right as workers in other industries to follow the career path of their choice.\n\n\"A footballer's career should not be tied to a transfer market which has spiraled out of control.\n\n\"FIFPro is not in a position to comment on the specifics of the situation of either Diego Costa.\n\n\"However, we are aware of repeated instances of the financial interests of clubs interfering with the short career of players.\n\n\"Indeed, FIFPro's recent global survey of professional players found that 29 per cent of those traded for a transfer fee to their current club were unhappy with the move.\"", "id": "9663692", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "'My I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys,\" he told the Daily Mail.\n\n\"I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\"\n\nThe Brazilian-born Spain international, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in 2014, said if the club did not allow him to move before the transfer window he was prepared to see out his contract unpaid in Brazil.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\n\n\"I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\"\n\nThe situation is complicated by the fact that Atletico are currently banned from signing players in this window although a loan deal would be possible.\n\nCosta's relationship with Conte appears to have broken down although the Brazilian accepts the Italian \"is a good
