{"timeCrawl": "18:09:00", "uri": "709375701", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T18:09:00Z", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "source": {"title": "Deadspin", "uri": "deadspin.com", "id": "3274"}, "url": "http://deadspin.com/diego-costa-is-hanging-out-at-home-and-talking-shit-abo-1797826559", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "The highlight of the first full weekend of hot Premier League action was not Manchester United flushing West Ham down the toilet, Wayne Rooney rescuing Everton, nor American ex-pat community Huddersfield Town winning their debut Premier League match 3-0. No, it was Antonio Conte's Chelsea side eating shit in hilarious and futile fashion to fucking Burnley, the team who scored the fewest goals of any top-flight team that escaped relegation last year. After dumbass Gary Cahill picked up a red card just 14 minutes in, Burnley turned on the jets and bagged three goals within halftime. Chelsea ended up scoring twice, losing Cesc Fabregas in the 81st minute, and eventually falling to the Clarets, 3-2. It owned so hard.\n\nNotably absent from the party was disgruntled Brazilian/Spanish striker Diego Costa. When he's on, Costa is a terrifying maniac of a striker, capable of wrecking defenses with thunderous runs and strong finishes. He scored 20 goals last season and was the top forward in the league for a good chunk of time,\n\nHowever, he's also a notoriously difficult personality who loves to fight and even as Chelsea were cruising to a league title last season, Costa was already butting heads with manager Antonio Conte. He got into a \"row\" with a fitness coach, then was dropped from the lineup before a marquee matchup with Leicester and reportedly told to take his ass to China. Costa got \"excused\" from preseason training while Chelsea spent the summer making eyes at every available striker in the world before finally signing young Spanish star \u00c1lvaro Morata for \u00a358 million.\n\nWhich brings us to this weekend, which Costa apparently spent watching Chelsea play while relaxing at his home in northeastern Brazil until a reporter from the Daily Mail just sort of showed up and got to watch it all unfold with him. Adam Crafton says he arrived at Costa's house in Lagarto right after Burnley scored their third goal, and got to hang with the Costa family. The results were delightful.\n\n'It's going well for Chelsea, isn't it?' he grimaces. 'The red card changed the game but anyway, you've come a long way and I have nothing to hide. Come on in.'\n\nCosta, who hasn't been with Chelsea since May, is all set to leave the club however he can, and he's been training by himself in Brazil while waiting for a transfer (ideally to Atl\u00e9tico Madrid). Costa would rather take the bath that comes with skipping out on his contract than train in London. He is no fan of Antonio Conte and didn't say he'd rule out legal action against the club, while also excoriating the manager.\n\nCosta's summer began with a text message from Conte, informing him his Chelsea career was over. Costa has not been at Chelsea since the FA Cup final in May and, during a half-hour conversation, the striker delivers a blistering retort.\n\nHe accuses Chelsea of treating him 'like a criminal' and refuses to rule out legal action. He says he will always keep Conte's text message on his phone and claims the Chelsea manager 'lacks charisma'. Costa also accuses Conte of blocking his contract negotiations in January.\n\nCosta said he respected Conte's soccer mind but basically called him a moron, a dick, and a coward.\n\n'What is happening now with Chelsea is sad,' he says. 'The text message -- I understand it when a coach wants a different player.\n\n'Alvaro Morata is a great player. He had a great season in Madrid and actually with the way this crazy transfer market is, I think they got a good price for a young and talented forward. He will triumph at Chelsea, but there are ways of going about it. You don't do it by text message. You should be honest and direct to someone's face.\n\n'I was with the Spain national team, alone in my room, when it came through. It was a shock to get it like that. I was showing it to my team-mates and they could not believe how he had done it.\n\n'I was angry at the time. Now I am more calm. I have not deleted the message. If people accuse me of lying, I can show them. It was clear, saying that he didn't count on me and wishing me the best for the future. Full stop.'\n\nBut it wasn't all shit talking and chest-puffing from Costa. He misses his buddies! They love him!\n\n'If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying \"I miss you\" and that they love me.\n\n'I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp.\n\n'They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.'\n\nIn the end, Diego Costa just loves sports and wants to play soccer again.", "id": "9137018", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", {"timeCrawl": "10:19:00", "uri": "710816059", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T10:19:00Z", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "source": {"title": "Belfast Telegraph", "uri": "belfasttelegraph.co.uk", "id": "226"}, "url": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/diego-costa-not-backing-down-over-his-wish-to-swap-chelsea-for-atletico-madrid-36041389.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "http://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/article36041388.ece/45add/AUTOCROP/h342/PANews%20BT_P-2d5a7836-91d8-4474-9fe5-56ff57af44fa_I1.jpg\n\nExiled striker Diego Costa has repeated his wish to return to Atletico Madrid and believes his stand-off with Chelsea will come to an end when he travels to Spain.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain international signed for \u00a332million from Atletico in July 2014, agreeing a five-year contract, and wishes to return to the Spanish capital.\n\nSpeaking from his native Lagarto earlier this week, Costa criticised Chelsea and head coach Antonio Conte.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by a text message sent by Conte during the off-season.\n\nBut the Blues insist it was decided in January, with the striker and his agent, Jorge Mendes, that Costa could leave this summer.\n\nAs a consequence, Costa has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection, as he still has two years remaining on his contract.\n\nCosta met with Milton Dantas, the president of the Sergipe Football Association, and afterwards reiterated his desire to return to Atletico. Sergipe is the region of Brazil where Costa is from.\n\nIn a statement released by Federacao Sergipana de Futebol and published by O Globo, Costa said: \"My destiny is already set.\n\n\"I must return to Atletico Madrid next season.\n\n\"There happens to be an impasse as Chelsea do not want to release me.\n\n\"But I believe this situation will be resolved upon my return to Spain.\"\n\nHe did not say when he would be returning to Spain, but his preferred move is complicated by Atletico's transfer embargo, which forbids them from registering new players until January.\n\nThe statement from the Sergipe FA is the first sign that Costa is prepared to use official channels to negotiate his departure from Stamford Bridge.\n\nPress Association Sport understands Costa has not yet contacted FIFA, football's world governing body, over his concerns.\n\nAnd FIFPro, the global players' union, is yet to by contacted by Costa.\n\nBut FIFPro has general concerns about the trade of players through transfers.\n\nA FIFPro statement said: \"We strongly believe that players at every level of the football pyramid should have the same right as workers in other industries to follow the career path of their choice.\n\n\"A footballer's career should not be tied to a transfer market which has spiraled out of control.\n\n\"FIFPro is not in a position to comment on the specifics of the situation of either Diego Costa.\n\n\"However, we are aware of repeated instances of the financial interests of clubs interfering with the short career of players.\n\n\"Indeed, FIFPro's recent global survey of I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen.\n\n\"His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.\"\n\n...\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go. If you were to ask all my team-mates, they'd say the same. They send messages saying \"I miss you\" and that they love me.\n\n\"I am always talking with the boys -- particularly Cesc Fabregas, David Luiz and Willian. We have banter over WhatsApp. They ask how I am. They really love me for the person I am. If they didn't, they wouldn't be saying they miss me and love me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico [Madrid]. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid.' I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\n...\n\n\"They want me to be there training with the reserves. I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me. I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live.\"\n\n18 days remain in the summer transfer window in Spain. off-field tensions and an awful start to the new campaign.\n\nChelsea have ordered Costa, who has two years left on a \u00a3180000-a-week contract, to return to the club from Brazil, train, get match-fit and put himself in contention for first-team selection.\n\nIt is the first hint of a route back into Conte's team for the 28-year-old striker who was told in a text from the manager in June that he was no longer in his plans.\n\nCosta was given permission to report a week late for pre-season training in the hope a transfer deal might be struck with Atletico Madrid, the only club he said he was prepared to leave Chelsea for.\n\nHe was expected back in mid-July and has been informed by the club that he had to report for training but he is yet to return.\n\nIn an exclusive interview {"timeCrawl": "23:38:00", "uri": "708955753", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T23:28:00Z", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/13/diego-costa-accuses-chelsea-of-being-unfair-and-treating-him-like-a-criminal", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa has accused Chelsea of treating him like a \"criminal\" and revealed he will not return to the club, who he still hopes will sanction his return to Atl\u00e9tico Madrid.\n\nThe 28-year-old striker, who has been told by Antonio Conte he has no future at Stamford Bridge, told the Daily Mail that the Chelsea manager lacks charisma and that he is happy to continue accepting fines for refusing to train with the reserves at the club's Cobham training base. \"They want me to be there training with the reserves,\" Costa said.\n\n\"I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact with the guys. I'm not a criminal. I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\n\n\"I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. You know that the manager doesn't want me. I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go.\"\n\nCosta made a text conversation with Conte - in which the Italian informed him his Chelsea career was over - public knowledge in June, insisting he \"would have to find a way out\" of the club. But Costa, who scored 20 Premier League goals to help Chelsea win the title last season, said he was close to agreeing a new contract as recently as January at Stamford Bridge but believes Conte intervened before he could put pen to paper.\n\n\"I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it,\" he said. \"I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen. His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that. But as a person -- no. He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess ... charisma.\"\n\nCosta remains hopeful of securing a return to Atl\u00e9tico, where he played for four years between 2010 and 2014 before joining Jos\u00e9 Mourinho's Chelsea. Costa admits the Manchester United manager has contacted him to \"check I am OK\" and insists he never had any problems with the Portuguese.\n\nHe adds he has informed the Chelsea director, Marina Granovskaia, of his intentions to depart for La Liga and that he has rejected offers to leave Chelsea, who he accuses of trying to sell him to Chinese clubs. \"I want the deal with Atl\u00e9tico resolved this month,\" added the Spain striker. \"My idea would be to go to Madrid, train there, get in the best physical shape and be ready to fire ahead of the World Cup.\"", "id": "8980027", year awards, a selection of player of the month gongs, and even a miniature Big Ben.\n\nDiego Costa's family home features many of his individual footballing awards on display\n\nThe family living room contains photos from his career at Chelsea and Atletico Madrid\n\nCosta spoke exclusively to Sportsmail's Adam Crafton about his footballing future\n\nCosta says, despite his refusal to return to Stamford Bridge for this season, that he remains close to the Blues players and grateful to his fans.\n\nThis is demonstrated by the presence of several reminders of his best days as a player at Chelsea, who he fired to the Premier League title twice in the last three years.\n\nCosta was named PFA Player of the Year in 2014/15, and that award sits in prime position in his trophy shelf, in the shelf is a large cup received from Spanish newspaper Marca, given to La Liga's top Spanish scorer.\n\nWhile Costa has an emotional connection to Chelsea, a playing return still seems remote\n\nThere are several other reminders of his Atletico career in photos of him around the TV, along with one of him and brother Jair as children.\n\nCosta has said he is only interested in I wouldn't be allowed access to the first-team dressing room and I would have no contact at all with the guys,\" he told the Daily Mail.\n\n\"I'm not a criminal! I don't think it is fair after all I have done to be treated like that.\"\n\nThe Brazilian-born Spain international, who joined Chelsea from Atletico Madrid in 2014, said if the club did not allow him to move before the transfer window he was prepared to see out his contract unpaid in Brazil.\n\n\"I am open to being a year in Brazil without playing, even if Chelsea fine me for a year and don't pay me. I'll come back stronger. If I was in the wrong, I'd go back now and do as they say.\n\n\"I want the deal with Atletico resolved this month. banned from signing players in this window although a loan deal would be possible.\n\nCosta's relationship with Conte appears to have broken down although the Brazilian accepts the Italian \"is a good {"timeCrawl": "06:49:00", "uri": "709620288", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T06:49:00Z", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "source": {"title": "Metro.co.uk", "uri": "metro.co.uk", "id": "218"}, "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/15/chelsea-tell-diego-costa-to-come-back-and-compete-for-first-team-place-6852748/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Chelsea tell Diego Costa to come back and compete for first-team place gossip\n\nMark Brus for Metro.co.ukTuesday 15 Aug 2017 7:38 am Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nChelsea have reportedly made the surprise demand to Diego Costa that he come back to training with the club in order to put himself in contention for a first-team place.\n\nThe Blues are concerned over the condition of the Spain international, who has been absent from the squad for some time amid a dispute over his future in this transfer window.\n\nRoman Abramovich to step in and spend \u00a3120m to prevent Chelsea's season from imploding\n\nAntonio Conte told Costa via text earlier this summer that he was no longer in his first-team plans, with a move to Atletico Madrid or AC Milan looking likely for some time as Alvaro Morata moved to Stamford Bridge as a likely replacement.\n\nHowever, a transfer has not yet materialised for Costa leading to reports last week that the club were concerned his lack of match fitness could hinder their chances of selling him.\n\nAccording to the Guardian, Chelsea now want Costa back in training to get himself fit and to challenge for a place in the first-team once again in a surprise development.\n\nWhile it seems likely that the Premier League champions merely want to get him back to his best to avoid a slump in his market value, it could also mean we haven't seen the last of the 28-year-old in a Chelsea shirt just yet.\n\nConte's side made a poor start to the season with a shock 3-2 home defeat to Burnley on Saturday, and haven't made as many signings as they'd hoped to this summer.\n\nCosta on Conte 'I have seen the sort of person he is. He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no.\n\n'He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. He doesn't possess charisma.'\n\nDiego Costa 2016/17 statsAppearances42Goals22Assists7\n\nShare\n\nNemanja Matic, John Terry, Asmir Begovic, Nathan Ake and Nathaniel Chalobah have also all left, leaving Conte short of the depth he wants going into the new season.\n\nThis seems to have handed Costa a surprise lifeline at Stamford Bridge, even if a long-term resolution still reportedly looks unlikely.\n\nThe player's relationship with the club and manager look to be at an all-time low after his explosive interview with the Daily Mail over the weekend, though this seems to have prompted some action from the Blues as they look to resolve a saga that has dragged on since the end of May.\n\nMORE: Fabregas ignored Conte's half-time instructions as furious Chelsea boss holds In my wildest dreams, I couldn't do that.\n\n\"I couldn't do it, Mark [Schwarzer, his fellow guest on The Debate] wouldn't do it and I know a lot of footballers who wouldn't.\n\nCosta: I won't return to Chelsea\n\nDiego Costa has released a statement saying he will not return to Chelsea and he \"must return to Atletico Madrid\".\n\n\"So there has got to be something in his make-up. Why would you buy someone who has got that in them to get up one morning, go home and say 'I'm not coming back'?\"\n\nWhile Costa may favour a move to Atletico Madrid, they are currently under a transfer embargo until January 2018 but Merson believes that if a transfer was to happen, the La Liga side would have the power.\n\n\"Atletico Madrid could be talking to another Spanish club and saying 'we will buy him and you take him on loan for six months for us',\" he added.\n\n\"It seems at the moment, Atletico Madrid are holding all the cards. They don't have to put in a \u00a350m, \u00a340m or \u00a330m bid. They know that he wants to come and could say 'we'll give you \u00a310m to take him off your hands'.\"\n\nFormer Blues goalkeeper Schwarzer believes Chelsea are doing the right thing by asking Costa to return and believes that the only person the situation affects is the striker himself.\n\n\"What they [Chelsea] should do is keep doing what they're doing. They've demanded that he comes back and he isn't. {"timeCrawl": "23:09:00", "uri": "711157010", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-17T23:09:00Z", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "source": {"title": "The Scottish Sun", "uri": "thescottishsun.co.uk", "id": "17001"}, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/sport/football/1435556/diego-costas-potential-exit-from-chelsea-leaves-a-sour-taste-in-mouths-of-fans-who-worshipped-him-at-stamford-bridge/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "The Blues striker is refusing to return to the Premier League champions as he pushes for a move to Atletico Madrid\n\nTHEY made the mistake of presenting Diego Costa as a true blue.\n\nInstead, it turns out he was just passing through.\n\nWhat a shame it's come to this for Chelsea and their snarling forward.\n\nTogether they lifted two League titles but the striking Brazilian will be remembered for taking on a ruthless Russian regime worth \u00a310bn.\n\nThere is no way back - just consciously uncoupling as the lawyers on both sides thrash out a costly, complicated agreement.\n\nCosta claims he is off to Spain to sit this out until Atletico Madrid and Chelsea agree a transfer fee for the volatile forward.\n\nChelsea, careful not to jeopardise their own legal position, are in no rush to do business and because of Atletico's transfer ban, Costa can't kick a ball for them until next January anyway.\n\nThe only winners in all this mess are the lawyers.\n\nCosta remains on Chelsea's books, with a gushing biography still on the website and some shiny new training kit with his squad number 19 neatly folded away at the training ground.\n\nCosta, scorer of 59 goals in 120 appearances for Chelsea, will never wear it again. He has made his position clear.\n\nOver the next few weeks, he intends to force through a return to Atletico, to be reunited with boss Diego Simeone in their sparkly new stadium on the outskirts of the city.\n\nFor some reason, he never quite took to life in London.\n\nThe neighbours frequently complained to the club about his late night parties and his fondness for a traditional Brazilian BBQ went too far.\n\nEven learning the language seemed too much of a chore for a player who relied on a translator whenever he needed to speak to a Chelsea official.\n\nWhen he was scoring goals - 20 in the league during last season's title triumph - Chelsea indulged him, protected him, lauded him.\n\nThey overlooked his frequent transgressions, his party-loving lifestyle and explosive, combustible personality. Instead, Chelsea seem to enjoy having him around the place.\n\nAlong with David Luiz, he was always one of the first to put his name forward when the club had visits from charities or from disadvantaged kids.\n\nThat manner, his ability to put a smile on the face of children and his fun-loving personality impressed the Stamford Bridge hierarchy.\n\nThey warmed to his petulant, mischievous manner, not to mention his goals.\n\nAnd he is a loss to the Premier League, of sorts.\n\nThis stand-off has put Chelsea in a tricky position with the 40,000 fans who idolised him, worshipped him and took to loving him.\n\nThey sold him as one of their own - presenting him as blue through and through when he tangled with Premier League defenders.\n\nHis iconic status and his relationship with the fans, means the club are tip-toeing around the issue as they cannot afford to alienate the supporters. Chelsea are aware that the fans, whatever the rights and wrongs of this grisly episode, would take him back in a heartbeat.\n\nThis loveable rogue, 28, signed from Atletico by Jose Mourinho in July 2014, could easily set their pulses racing again.\n\nThey would flutter their eyelashes and think back to that majestic double one-two against Southampton last April before he beat Fraser Forster from close range.\n\nThey would laugh at the time when he lifted his armpits and gestured to Stoke captain Ryan Shawcross that he pen and inks.\n\nOr they would get giddy about the moment that he ambushed Antonio Conte's title-winning press conference at the Hawthorns by threatening to set off a fire extinguisher.\n\nBut Costa is an old flame now. His lawyers are relying on the text message Conte sent, without the authorisation of the Chelsea board, to get him out this hole.\n\nWhile he is in it, digging himself deeper and deeper, Chelsea have taken to fining him one week's wages for each week he does not show up at Cobham.\n\nCosta being Costa, he intends to fight it.\n\nWhen it comes to the crunch, the Blues, of course, have some ammo of their own. To start with, there are the four separate transfers requests Costa has made since Conte arrived at Stamford Bridge in 2016.\n\nAfter the first, during the club's pre-season tour to America that summer, Costa refused to train for three days.\n\nHe made a further attempt to get away before the season started, another in January when he wanted to move to China and now this.\n\nIt has disrupted Chelsea's preparations for the season - far more than anybody ever realised before last Saturday's chaotic 3-2 home defeat against Burnley.\n\nThey will be missing captain Gary Cahill and Cesc Fabregas against Tottenham at Wembley on Sunday after their red cards on the opening weekend.\n\nAnd Conte will also be without another player, a guy who could have made all the difference on a day like that.\n\nSadly, Costa will never be able to pull on that blue shirt again.", "id": "9792211", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-17", "title": "Diego Costa's potential exit leaves sour taste for I'm coming in now to Chelsea saying 'look, you're clearly prepared to do it having sold [Nemanja] Matic to a title rival in Man United'.\n\n\"Liverpool are crying out for a forward of Costa's ilk and so are Everton. If they want to get into that top four consistently and do well in the Champions League - Everton in the Europa League - you could do a lot worse than Diego Costa.\n\n\"He (Costa) knows the model - he's done it consistently over the last few years.\n\n\"If I was Ronald Koeman or Jurgen Klopp I'd be on the phone to Chelsea trying to get that done.\"\n\nCosta has had a rocky relationship with Chelsea head coach Antonio Conte since the Italian arrived at Stamford Bridge.\n\nThe forward wanted to leave the Blues in January 2017 when a big-money offer was submitted from China, and he was dropped from Conte's squad after a row over his future.\n\nThough he remained in London, and helped fire Chelsea to the Premier League title, Barton believes the current situation is a continuation of the troubles started last season.\n\nHe added: \"I think this all distils down to the January window, when he was linked with the move to China. {"timeCrawl": "00:29:00", "uri": "711179795", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T00:29:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"title": "Irish Examiner", "uri": "irishexaminer.com", "id": "817"}, "url": "http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/soccer/diego-costa-still-playing-hardball-457289.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "Exiled striker Diego Costa has repeated his wish to return to Atletico Madrid and believes his stand-off with Chelsea will come to an end when he travels to Spain.\n\nThe 28-year-old Brazil-born Spain international signed for \u00a332million from Atletico in July 2014, agreeing a five-year contract, and wishes to return to the Spanish capital.\n\nSpeaking from his native Lagarto earlier this week, Costa criticised Chelsea and head coach Antonio Conte.\n\nCosta claims he was told he was not wanted by a text message sent by Conte during the off-season.\n\nBut the Blues insist it was decided in January, with the striker and his agent, Jorge Mendes, that Costa could leave this summer.\n\nAs a consequence, Costa has been ordered by Chelsea to return to London, get himself match fit and make himself available for selection, as he still has two years remaining on his contract.\n\nCosta met with Milton Dantas, the president of the Sergipe Football Association, and afterwards reiterated his desire to return to Atletico. Sergipe is the region of Brazil where Costa is from.\n\nIn a statement released by Federacao Sergipana de Futebol and published by O Globo, Costa said: \"My destiny is already set. I must return to Atletico Madrid next season. There happens to be an impasse as Chelsea do not want to release me.\n\n\"But I believe this situation will be resolved upon my return to Spain.\"\n\nHe did not say when he would be returning to Spain, but his preferred move is complicated by Atletico's transfer embargo, which forbids them from registering new players until January.\n\nCosta has not yet contacted Fifa, football's world governing body, over his concerns. And FIFPro, the global players' union, is yet to by contacted by Costa.\n\nBut FIFPro has general concerns about the trade of players through transfers.\n\nA FIFPro statement said: \"We strongly believe that players at every level of the football pyramid should have the same right as workers in other industries to follow the career path of their choice.\n\n\"A footballer's career should not be tied to a transfer market which has spirraled out of control.\n\n\"FIFPro is not in a position to comment on the specifics of the situation of either Diego Costa.\n\n\"However, we are aware of repeated instances of the financial interests of clubs interfering with the short career of players.\n\nMeanwhile Tottenham look set to run out in front of a near Premier League record crowd for their first home match at Wembley against Chelsea on Sunday, but have not been able to put tickets on full general sale at the 90,000-seater national stadium.\n\nSpurs have relocated Wembley, where they played last season's home Champions League fixtures, while White Hart Lane is being redeveloped, a project which eventually see the north London club return to a new 61,559-capacity venue.\n\nBrent Council has allowed Tottenham to use Wembley's full seat allocation of 90,000 for every home match, but restrictions have been put in place on the Chelsea fixture following discussions with the stadium's Safety Advisory Group.\n\nAs such only those Spurs fans who were registered on the club's database before July 1 2017 are permitted to purchase seats during the restricted general sale window, a measure which aims to prevent any away supporters from gaining access to the designated home sections at Wembley.\n\nThe current record attendance for a Premier League match stands at 76,073 when Manchester United played Aston Villa at Old Trafford in January 2007.\n\nTicket sales for Spurs game against Chelsea have already passed the 70,000 mark, including an allocation of some 3,000 to away fans, with still three days left before the game which is set to be broadcast live on Sky Sports.\n\nGiven the segregation which is required to be in place around the stadium, as well as the restrictions on sales the club are permitted to make, it is unlikely, though, that Sunday's match will provide a bigger attendance than the 85,512 for a Champions League fixture against Bayer Leverkusen last season which was a record crowd for an English club.\n\nEach Spurs match at Wembley is considered by the stadium's Safety Advisory Group on an individual basis, with tickets for {"timeCrawl": "09:43:00", "uri": "710232810", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T09:43:00Z", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "source": {"title": "Metro.co.uk", "uri": "metro.co.uk", "id": "218"}, "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/16/diego-costa-should-be-winding-up-antonio-conte-even-more-says-ian-wright-6856445/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa should be winding up Antonio Conte even more, says Ian Wright Simon Rice for Metro.co.ukWednesday 16 Aug 2017 10:24 am Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nChelsea star Diego Costa has got his tactics totally wrong in his feud with Antonio Conte, says Ian Wright.\n\nThe striker is currently at loggerheads with the Chelsea manager and refusing to return to training.\n\nArsene Wenger tips Arsenal star to be finest of his generation\n\nThe situation was sparked by Conte sending the Spain international a text to inform him he was no longer wanted at Stamford Bridge. It's understood the Italian tactician has grown fed up with Costa's antics.\n\nCosta is currently in Brazil, refusing to train with the club.\n\nBut according to Wright, this only plays into Conte's hands. The former Arsenal striker thinks that Costa could cause more problems for Conte if he returned - which is what he should do.\n\n'He should be back at Chelsea training. It says in his contract that you have to be there fit and ready if selected whatever happens,' the former England striker told Sky Sports.\n\n'I don't know if somewhere along the line, that's gone out of the window with players because as soon as they don't want to be there, they go on strike. He's still in Brazil and the season has started and he's not fit. He should have reported back for pre-season and it is terrible professionalism.\n\nChelsea 2017/18 Fixtures\n\nTottenham (A) - Sat Aug 20\n\nEverton (H) - Sun Aug 27\n\nLeicester City (A) - Sat Sep 9\n\nArsenal (H) - Sun Sep 17\n\nStoke City (A) - Sat Sep 23\n\n'I think that the vibe I get off of it is that Conte is delighted that he's not in and around the place. Costa should have read the situation properly and thought \"if I'm around, it's going to irk him even more\". I feel like that's the scenario Costa should have gone down.\n\n'I get the impression from Conte that if Costa's around [the club] and he's in [Conte's] face, that's going to be a problem and that's what Costa should be doing. Him and his agents have read it wrong.'\n\nSpeaking in Brazil, Costa indicated he had no intention of returning by revealing he was prepared to take any fines the club punished him with.\n\n'They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way,' he told the Daily Mail.\n\n'I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. You can never go against a club. You are never going to win,' Melchiot told talkSPORT.\n\n'You can try as hard as you want, but the club has the longest breath. The 28-year-old still has two years to run on his Chelsea contract, and although manager Antonio Conte has informed the Spain striker he is not in his plans, the club fully expect Costa to return to training and make himself available for selection as a Chelsea player.\n\nCosta said last week he felt Chelsea had treated him \"like a criminal\" for ordering him to train away from Conte's first-team group and for fining him for failing to report to pre-season training. Chelsea have dismissed Costa's latest comments, as reported by the Brazilian newspaper O Globo. The German champions are ready to let Sanches depart a year after he joined the club, even if it is on loan. Chelsea have been interested in the 19 year-old but Sanches has reportedly snubbed the Blues in favour of AC Milan where he can expect more first team opportunities.\n\nGetty Images\n\n5/6 Fabinho 3/10\n\nManchester United hotly pursued a move for Monaco's defensive midfielder before turning their attention to Matic. Fabinho caught the eyes of Europe's elite when staring in Monaco's title winning side but the French club are determined to hold onto the Brazilian. In a statement Monaco's vice president made it very clear that Fabinho is an 'essential player' and will be staying. Chelsea have already prised away on of Monaco's central midfielders when they spent \u00a335million on Tiemoue Bakayoko which makes Fabinho an unlikely prospect.\n\nBongarts/Getty Images\n\n6/6 Eric Dier 3/10\n\nTottenham were reluctant to let Manchester United speak to Eric Dier who was reportedly open to a move away from Spurs. Mauricio Pochettino's refusal to let Dier leave for United makes the Englishman a difficult target for Chelsea who have soured their relationship with the north London club in recent years.\n\nTottenham Hotspur FC via Getty I\n\n\"They gave me a week extra off but since then it's fines all the way. They want me training with the reserves. I am not going to do that. I am not a criminal and I am not in the wrong here. So, if they need to fine me, let them fine me.\n\n\"I take the hit every week but I'm not driven by money. The important thing is to be happy with how I live. I'm here with my parents and people who respect me.\"\n\nRead more Costa reveals United boss Mourinho called him while in Chelsea exile\n\nCosta has two years to run on his contract and while a move to Atletico - where he played for four seasons - is his ideal conclusion, he says he would happily stay in Brazil for a year and not play.\n\n\"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me? I have to do what I have to do. I have to think of myself. I've been a good boy here and tried to do the right thing.\n\n\"My desire is to go to Atletico. I've spoken to Chelsea director Marina Granovskaia. I said, 'If the manager doesn't want me, I want to go to Atletico Madrid'.\n\nCosta also accused Conte of halting his contract negotiations in January and revealed that he had turned down offers from China.\n\n\"I am waiting for Chelsea to set me free. I didn't want to leave. I was happy. When the manager does not want you, you have to go,\" Costa added.\n\n\"I have rejected other offers. They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to -- not the club that's paying the most.\n\n\"[Atleti manager] Diego Simeone wants me. It is very clear. I have always had a bond with him. The fans and people love me there. They respect me.\"\n\nMore about: Diego Costa Chelsea F.c. The fiery Spain international is attracting interest from AC Milan and Atletico Madrid but is currently training alone, with a move away from the capital far from completion.\n\nChelsea are intent on selling Costa, who they value at \u00a344m (\u20ac48.6m, $57.3m) but Townsend thinks the club are seeing the forward's value decrease due to the needless stand-off.\n\nTownsend, who enjoyed a three-year stint at Chelsea between 1990 and 1993, says Costa should be trying to disrupt Conte's plans at the champions' training complex in Cobham instead of sulking 5,500 miles away in Brazil, where he is \"not a problem\" for the Italian.\n\n\"As a player, if he wanted to get under Conte's skin and get out of the club, he should have come back. {"timeCrawl": "08:46:00", "uri": "709663550", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-15T08:46:00Z", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "source": {"title": "The Irish Times", "uri": "irishtimes.com", "id": "1154"}, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/chelsea-tell-diego-costa-to-return-to-london-and-prove-fitness-1.3187252", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Chelsea have responded firmly to Diego Costa claims of maltreatment, demanding the striker return to training and get himself fit for first-team selection.\n\nThe Premier League champions have been forced to respond after Costa gave an interview from his home in Brazil where he claimed that Chelsea had treated him \"like a criminal\" over his desire to leave the club this summer.\n\nIt is understood Chelsea have made four demands of the player if he is to restore relations that have been badly soured even before this weekend's interview. The first is straightforward, that he should return to the club. The second is that he should report for training, the third that he get match fit and the fourth, and most surprising, that he put himself into contention for first-team selection.\n\nThe 28-year-old has been in dispute with Chelsea's coach, Antonio Conte, since the turn of the year when the Brazilian-born Spain international was upbraided for a row with the fitness coach Julio Tous. After a disappointing second half to last season, Conte told the player he was surplus to requirements by text message, the contents of which Costa then made public.\n\nCosta is believed to have been absent without leave from Chelsea since the club flew to China for a pre-season tour in the middle of July. The club have refused to discuss the nature of any disciplinary proceedings against the player, but Costa claimed in his interview with the Daily Mail that he has had his wages docked since that time.\n\nThe ensuing stand-off led to Chelsea's most prized forward watching his club's opening defeat by Burnley on his parent's TV in the Brazilian city of Lagarto. Chelsea's intervention in the dispute has at least set out the club's stall but it looks unlikely to defuse the situation, at least in the short term.\n\nCosta now knows the conditions through which he can make peace with the club. But while there are precedents for such disputes ending with the player returning to the field, as Carlos Tevez did for Manchester City after absconding to Argentina in 2010, such an outcome would seem unlikely.\n\nPerhaps the best Costa can hope for is to engender some goodwill, helping him work towards his preferred resolution: a return to his former club Atl\u00e9tico Madrid. Atl\u00e9tico, however, have yet to meet Chelsea's valuation for the player. They remain an interested party watching on as a struggle for power between player and employee continues.\n\nCosta signed for Chelsea from Atl\u00e9tico in the summer of 2014 for \u00a332m. He won the league with the club in his first season, scoring 21 goals in the process. He managed only 16 goals the following season (and 11 yellow cards) as Chelsea suffered a remarkable collapse.\n\nThe appointment of Conte appeared to galvanise the forward once again with Costa scoring 15 goals before Christmas. {"timeCrawl": "01:27:00", "uri": "710056165", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-16T01:27:00Z", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "source": {"title": "Heart", "uri": "heart.co.uk", "id": "1019"}, "url": "http://www.heart.co.uk/news/sport/diego-costa-should-be-back-at-chelsea-accordi/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa should be back at Chelsea if he wants to make a move away from the club happen quickly, according to Andy Townsend and Ian Wright.\n\nThe duo were quizzed on the future of the striker on The Debate after the Spain international gave an interview with the Daily Mail saying he would go on strike to seal a move away from Stamford Bridge.\n\nCosta is currently in his home country of Brazil, but Townsend says he should be back at Chelsea to try and make any potential move go through quicker as well as being fit for action at a new club.\n\n\"As a player, if he wanted to get under Conte's skin and get out of the club, he should have come back. He should be here with a big smile on his face every day,\" the former Blues midfielder told The Debate.\n\n\"Conte looks like the type of man that thinks 'if you get in the way of what I really want to do every day, you are going to bug me and annoy me'. And I'd be knocking on the owner's door asking him to take the problem away.\n\n\"But sitting in Brazil, he's not a problem to Conte. If a move happens tomorrow, are you telling me he's in the best shape to turn up at a new club and start playing? Of course he's not.\n\n\"I think the player has done this wrong. Forget the text, so what if he was hurt by it? He should have come back, he should get himself ready to go but he should make it absolutely clear to Conte that he doesn't want to stay and play for him.\n\n\"If he said that, I'm sure things would start moving a bit quicker. All of this bravado from the other side of the world isn't getting him anywhere quick. Do your work, do your training, pick your wages up, appear to be a good pro on the face of it and be ready for selection but you can make it loud and clear in other ways that your time is done.\n\n\"The communication here has got so lost along the line. To be champions one minute and when there is a dearth of fantastic No 9's around the world, he is one of them. As an asset, Chelsea are losing millions on this guy. It defies any logic really.\"\n\nHis sentiments were echoed by former striker Wright, who says Costa has shown 'terrible professionalism' by choosing to stay in Brazil and should go about the situation in a different way.\n\n\"He should be back at Chelsea training. It says in his contract that you have to be there fit and ready if selected whatever happens,\" he said.\n\n\"I don't know if somewhere along the line, that's gone out of the window with players because as soon as they don't want to be there, they go on strike. He's still in Brazil and the season has started and he's not fit. He should have reported back for pre-season and it is terrible professionalism.\n\n\"I think that the vibe I get off of it is that Conte is delighted that he's not in and around the place. Costa should have read the situation properly and thought 'if I'm around, it's going to irk him even more'. I feel like that's the scenario Costa should have gone down.\n\n\"I get the impression from Conte that if Costa's around [the club] and he's in [Conte's] face, that's going to be a problem and that's what Costa should be doing. {"timeCrawl": "19:15:00", "uri": "709401493", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T19:03:00Z", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/14/diego-costa-chelsea-dispute-antonio-conte", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Chelsea have responded firmly to Diego Costa claims of maltreatment, demanding the striker return to training and get himself fit for first-team selection.\n\nThe Premier League champions have been forced to respond after Costa gave an interview from his home in Brazil where he claimed that Chelsea had treated him \"like a criminal\" over his desire to leave the club this summer.\n\nIt is understood Chelsea have made four demands of the player if he is to restore relations that have been badly soured even before this weekend's interview. The first is straightforward, that he should return to the club. The second is that he should report for training, the third that he get match fit and the fourth, and most surprising, that he put himself into contention for first-team selection.\n\nThe 28-year-old has been in dispute with Chelsea's coach, Antonio Conte, since the turn of the year when the Brazilian-born Spain international was upbraided for a row with the fitness coach Julio Tous. After a disappointing second half to last season, Conte told the player he was surplus to requirements by text message, the contents of which Costa then made public.\n\nCosta is believed to have been absent without leave from Chelsea since the club flew to China for a pre-season tour in the middle of July. The club have refused to discuss the nature of any disciplinary proceedings against the player, but Costa claimed in his interview with the Daily Mail that he has had his wages docked since that time.\n\nThe ensuing stand off led to Chelsea's most prized forward watching his club's opening defeat by Burnley on his parent's TV in the Brazilian city of Lagarto. Chelsea's intervention in the dispute has at least set out the club's stall but it looks unlikely to defuse the situation, at least in the short term. Costa now knows the conditions through which he can make peace with the club. But while there are precedents for such disputes ending with the player returning to the field, as Carlos Tevez did for Manchester City after absconding to Argentina in 2010, such an outcome would seem unlikely.\n\nPerhaps the best Costa can hope for is to engender some goodwill, helping him work towards his preferred resolution: a return to his former club Atl\u00e9tico Madrid. Atl\u00e9tico, however, have yet to meet Chelsea's valuation for the player. They remain an interested party watching on as a struggle for power between player and employee continues.\n\nCosta signed for Chelsea from Atl\u00e9tico in the summer of 2014 for \u00a332m. He won the league with the club in his first season scoring 21 goals in the process. He managed only 16 goals the following season (and 11 yellow cards) as Chelsea suffered a remarkable collapse. The appointment of Conte appeared to galvanise the forward once again with Costa scoring 15 goals before Christmas. But the rubbing up of two combustible personalities has resulted in a conflagration that those at Stamford Bridge are struggling to put out.", "id": "9146388", "details": {}, "date": "2017-08-14", {"timeCrawl": "16:08:00", "uri": "709321274", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T16:02:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"title": "The Guardian", "uri": "theguardian.com", "id": "260"}, "url": "http://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/14/diego-costa-chelsea-transfer-atletico-madrid", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "W hat's your favourite Diego Costa moment? Perhaps it's the one where he manages to get Gabriel Paulista sent off for a retaliatory kick just by standing quite near him muttering and smiling like some horrible, handsome, impossibly terrible footballing Iago.\n\nOr the 2-2 draw with Tottenham where Mark Clattenburg books 12 players but not actually Costa, who has a hand in at least five of those yellows, all the while maintaining an attitude of prim and saintly innocence. Or the 3-1 defeat of Arsenal where Costa \"scare-assists\" his team's final goal by running towards Petr Cech and making Arsenal's goalkeeper perform his best impression of Shaggy from Scooby Doo confronted by a double-dealing fairground owner in a zombie mask.\n\nNow we have this, the endless summer of Diego. As of this week Costa has spent half the summer and the opening week of the Premier League season holed up in his family home in Lagardo pretending to be inconsolably offended by a text message, all the while painting his current employers as bounders, cads, insufficiently \"respectful\" and so on. And in the process raising some genuinely profound issues about transfer fees and freedom of movement that have troubled even the biggest clubs for some time.\n\nIt is now 22 years since the Bosman decision in the European Court of Justice. Its effects are still working their way through football. What is certain is that the game has been transformed around it. And that clubs, governing bodies and players' representatives all know we're not quite done with a process that might just have taken a step forward this summer.\n\nBut back to Diego. Let's face it, given the raw human material involved there was always a chance Costa's time at Chelsea would end in a mess. Footballers are often described as being up for the fight. Costa isn't just up for it. He is the fight, a man whose entire concept of sport is based on a no-holds barred test of all human capacities, including the mental resilience to rise above the goadings of a sharp-elbowed striker with an infuriating line in wounded innocence.\n\nCosta has been a stellar Premier League player through two league titles, 57 goals and almost 400 fouls. It has been wonderful theatre at times. But at the end of this only the hardest heart could fail to raise a smirk of schadenfreude at the sight of Chelsea's chief weapon of footballing chaos turning his guns on his own employer.\n\nThe situation is unlikely to have been eased by Costa's comments in a fascinating interview in the Daily Mail. Relaxing on full pay at his family home, Costa suggested Chelsea are \"treating him like a criminal\". Like Ariel, the harmless sprite of the forest, all he craves is to be \"set free\" - agents, contracts, and sole approved destination pending.\n\nLike a drunken row on a bus, it can take a while to understand exactly what everyone's arguing about. A quick recap on how we got here. In January Costa was dropped briefly after some unrest behind the scenes and reports of a huge offer from China. Chelsea let it be known they had no intention of selling. Later that month Tianjin Quanjian said plans to sign Costa had been scuppered by new Chinese Super League rules. Costa suggested he had no intention of moving to China anyway.\n\nNobody really knows the exact ins and out of this mid-season shemozzle. All that is certain is Costa has been linked with a move away throughout his time at Chelsea; that his form dropped off a cliff after that; and that Antonio Conte sent Costa a text message in early June that apparently read: \"Hi Diego, I hope you are well. Thanks for the season we spent together. Good luck for next year but you are not in my plan.\"\n\nCosta immediately leaked this to Spanish TV. His brother Jair announced that Costa was all set on moving on and had had \"lots of offers\". Since when he has been at home in Lagardo, refusing to train at Chelsea, yawning off his club fines and now smiling, a little sadly, at his team's understandable state of confusion on the opening day of the Premier League season.\n\nAt the end which three things seem clear. First the offending text message looks quite polite, all things considered. Certainly it's more conciliatory than the text Costa might have received in similar circumstances from, say, Brian Clough, or Stan Cullis. Footballing mores dictate that players simply don't behave like this.\n\n\"In January, things happened with the coach,\" he has said. \"I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it. I suspect the manager was behind it.\" Well, yes Diego. This is how football works. You don't get to upset the coach mid-season and still have him warmly support your offer of a new contract.\n\nFrom a purely footballing view he has no real gripe. Players are shifted on all the time, and hear about it in far less courteous fashion. Costa has already been replaced, and replaced well, by \u00c1lvaro Morata. The path from here is well trodden. Get fit. Find a new club. And stop bleating on about respect.\n\nAt which point things get complicated. \"Why won't they let me go if they don't want me?\" Costa has asked. \"I want to go to Atl\u00e9tico Madrid.\"\n\nThe most obvious answer to which, not stated but implied, is that Chelsea are either refusing to sell, given the knock down price Costa would fetch right now; or asking a price Atl\u00e9tico Madrid are unwilling to pay.\n\n\"I have rejected other offers,\" Costa goes on. \"They want to sell me to China or other teams. The language is better for me in Spain. If I'm off, I'm going to the club I want to go to, not the club that's paying the most.\"\n\nAt which point, if you listen closely, you can hear the entire superheated industry of professional club football starting to quiver. Costa's lawyer has already suggested he will use \"all legal mechanisms\" to get the move he wants. How would this work in practice? In the real non-footballing world it seems laughable you could be denied the right to leave your job and work for another employer, or told only certain selected future employers are acceptable.\n\nFootball has come a long way since the retain and transfer system, whereby a player's registration was owned by his club, who could in extremis refuse to release it and force an ex-employee into retirement. The Eastham judgment in 1963 relaxed this owner-and-chattel relationship. Bosman attacked clubs' rights to have a say on a player's employment beyond the end of his contract. Other rulings have already suggested there is headway to be made challenging further the power of clubs to \"own\" a player's employment prospects.\n\nCosta aside, this is a huge live issue given the number of top footballers currently out with a bad case of wanting to play for someone else. Philippe Coutinho wants to work for Barcelona. Virgil van Dijk wanted to work for Liverpool. Both have broken the code by taking steps to decide their own professional destiny.\n\nFootball will remain a special case. Clubs must be protected. Academies and player production systems must be presented with an incentive to produce footballers and stop the whole ramshackle circus from falling to pieces. But for all his infuriating sense of entitlement, his clod-hopping failed powerplay, Costa is undoubtedly on to something.\n\nThree things are possible from here. Conte leaves before Costa does and the most improbable of Premier League comebacks becomes a very, very distant possibility. Chelsea and Atl\u00e9tico reach an agreement that makes this whole sorry mess disappear. Or, at a long shot, the man known during his Albacete days as \"that fucking Brazilian\" gets to wreak his own peculiar havoc on football's transfer system at a time when, quite frankly, anything seems possible out there.", "id": "9116298", "details": {"liCnt": 5}, "date": "2017-08-14", "title": "Despite this clod-hopping powerplay, Diego Costa may be on to something | Barney Ronay", "image": {"timeCrawl": "06:40:00", "uri": "709070624", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T06:40:00Z", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "source": {"title": "Metro.co.uk", "uri": "metro.co.uk", "id": "218"}, "url": "http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/14/diego-costa-aims-parting-shot-at-distant-chelsea-boss-antonio-conte-6850252/", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Diego Costa aims parting shot at 'distant' Chelsea boss Antonio Conte Louis Sealey for Metro.co.ukMonday 14 Aug 2017 7:39 am Share this article with Facebook Share this article with Twitter Share this article with Google Plus Share this article with Whatsapp Share this article through email Share this article through sms\n\nDiego Costa has aimed a parting shot at Antonio Conte, claiming the 'distant' Chelsea boss is not 'close to his players'.\n\nThe Spaniard is set to leave Stamford Bridge despite scoring over 20 goals last season after Conte told him via text that he was free to leave.\n\nBarcelona trolled as Deulofeu replaces Neymar while former star excels on PSG debut\n\nCosta admits Conte, who won the Premier League in his debut season in England, is a 'great coach' but questioned his relationship with the players at Chelsea.\n\nSpeaking to the Daily Mail, Costa said: 'In January, things happened with the coach. I was on the brink of renewing my contract and they put the brakes on it.\n\n'I suspect the manager was behind it. He asked for that to happen. His ideas are very fixed and clear. I have seen the sort of person he is.\n\n'He has his own opinion and that will not change. I respect him as a great coach. He has done a good job and I can see that, but as a person, no.\n\n'He is not a coach who is very close with his players. He is very distant. {"timeCrawl": "11:23:00", "uri": "711408535", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-18T06:01:00Z", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "source": {"title": "Goal.com", "uri": "goal.com", "id": "1734"}, "url": "http://www.goal.com/en-au/news/morata-will-make-chelsea-forget-about-diego-costa-but-their/x844g37u0ad81o5wgge7l9bt8", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3368442", "body": "Former Blues defender Graeme Le Saux thinks that his club have found the perfect replacement for last season's top scorer in their \u00a368 million hitman\n\nEXCLUSIVE\n\nGraeme Le Saux believes that Alvaro Morata's quality will help Chelsea fans forget about Diego Costa as the saga regarding the latter's sale to Atletico Madrid rumbles on.\n\nMorata 9/1 to be PL top scorer\n\nCosta proclaimed that \"I must return to Atletico Madrid\" in his latest statement as his divorce from Chelsea turns ugly with legal action ongoing between both parties.\n\nRelated Everton open to signing Diego Costa - Koeman Robson hails Manchester United signing Matic from Chelsea as a masterstroke Chelsea transfer news: The latest & LIVE player rumours from Stamford Bridge Diego Costa: I won't go back to Chelsea, I must return to Atletico Madrid\n\nMeanwhile, the Blues have begun their title defence with a 3-2 loss at home to Burnley and now face their London rivals Tottenham on Sunday. Morata scored and assisted on his full debut and Le Saux feels that his former club's new \u00a368 million hitman will be a perfect replacement for Costa.\n\n\"When I look at his quality, he has had fantastic experiences at the clubs that he has been at,\" he told Goal. \"He has always scored goals, his movement is excellent. He does a lot of hard work before the ball comes to him. He is always aware of what's around him.\n\n\"The timing of his run for that Willian cross [against Burnley] was great and how he kept himself onside. He got a run on the defender and it was a confident header. He has plenty of ability and attributes.\n\n\"It will have done him a world of good to get off to such a fantastic start but as for him replacing Diego Costa, it is a big task. Costa scored 20 goals last season and 20 goals three seasons ago when Chelsea won the title then as well.\n\n\"Costa is a very adaptive player who is versatile and holds the ball up well. It is a real shame to see what's happening there because he is a really good player. It is a disappointing situation to see it get to where it has.\n\n\"I think over time, Morata, if he continues to do what he did, will settle in and lead the line very well.\"\n\nMorata came off the bench to make his debut against Burnely, and his impressive cameo may earn him his first start in the London derby at Wembley against Tottenham in place of the underwhelming Michy Batshuayi.\n\nHowever, despite not being with the team, Costa has stolen the headlines this week after conducting an unsanctioned interview in his native Brazil. Costa has been ordered back to training so Chelsea can maintain his fitness and value but he has so far remained in the country of his birth.\n\nLe Saux made 192 appearances for Chelsea and thinks that these situations aren't uncommon. He also believes Chelsea's players can put Costa's situation out of their minds and aim for three points on Sunday.\n\n\"I think it goes all the way back to last Christmas when he tried to leave then,\" Le Saux added. \"I thought that the club, manager and players handled that situation really well because they managed to not let it detract from what they were doing in the league and not affect anyone.\n\n\"Costa deserves credit for that as well but now, it strikes me that [Antonio] Conte can't wait to cut him loose. I think when you are in that environment, you need to know everybody is committed to that same cause. As soon as you find out someone isn't you lose trust and faith in them.\"\n\nChelsea will have a youthful bench against Tottenham, just as they did against Burnley and Arsenal in the Community Shield, with the likes of Kyle Scott, Charly Musonda and Jeremie Boga having been promoted to the first team as injuries and suspensions hit the squad.\n\nConte has also hinted at wanting more signings before transfer deadline day and Le Saux, who was once English football's most expensive defender, agrees that his former club need more.\n\n\"What I felt, even toward the end of last season is that Chelsea might strengthen their wing-back positions,\" he added. \"That's not because Victor Moses and Marcos Alonso aren't first choice or good enough but I think it is such a demanding and specialist position that it is Chelsea's one area that they needed to strengthen.\n\n\"They needed a replacement for Costa and have that. They have Rudiger and the injured Bakayoko as well so another couple of players and getting the injured players back on the bench and in the team will make the squad look better. At the moment, it does look a little bit too thin.\n\nArsenal's Alex Oxlade-Chamberlain, Everton's Ross Barkley and Leicester City's Danny Drinkwater are among the talents that Chelsea are targeting with the transfer window due to close in a fortnight.\n\nChelsea appear to be looking to English talent, with a squad lacking in homegrown players, and Le Saux hopes that England's national team can benefit from seeing one of their players arriving at Stamford Bridge.\n\n\"I think first of all, the club looks for the type of player and they worry about the nationality second. At the same time, I think to see any England players at top-eight or top-six clubs is a good thing. It really is because I want English players at every level of our game in large clubs.\n\n\"English players at top-eight clubs are getting fantastic experience with their team-mates, learning a lot as well and learning those demands of the highest level of football.\"\n\nArticle continues below\n\nGraeme Le Saux was speaking on behalf of TAG Heuer to promote the TAG Heuer Premier League Pressure Test. How does Antonio Conte keep the grenades being lobbed in by his exiled star striker from blowing apart dressing-room morale?\n\nIt will be some achievement if the champions can respond to yet another week of controversy, suspensions and in-fighting by beating Spurs, the best-balanced team in the Premier League.\n\nTo be fair to Chelsea, they are doing their best to declare their war with Costa over.\n\nConte will dismiss it publicly yet again in his pre-match press conference on Friday and claim to be more focused on the weekend's trip to Wembley to face Tottenham.\n\nTrouble is, for Costa the war goes on.\n\nFor him, it is his way - an instant move to Atletico Madrid -- or the highway.\n\nSo when he does finally leave Brazil within the next few days it will be for Spain, not London.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\nChelsea's demand this week, for him to return to their Cobham HQ, get fit and make himself available for selection has carried about as much authority as a Donald Trump speech.\n\nWorse still for Conte, there are players in the dressing room unhappy that the man who shot them to two titles in the last three season remains out in the cold. It wouldn't take a great leap to count the Blues' Spanish contingent as being among that number.\n\nIt is a continuing crisis for a man knee-deep in it this summer:\n\n* Costa has no compunction about keeping up the fight against the club and, in particular, Conte.\n\nVideo Loading Video Unavailable Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8Cancel Play now\n\n* The Italian is at odds with the Chelsea board over transfer policy, who were not best pleased that he jumped the gun with THAT text to Costa.\n\n* The players are concerned the squad is still too thin to compete on four fronts.\n\n* And the fans can see that, once again, the club are in danger of shooting themselves in the foot after working so hard to make themselves champions.\n\nThe biggest fear is that the man who did so well to win so many people over in his debut campaign last season, could walk away .\n\nChelsea won't change -- with some justification.\n\nThe set-up under Roman Abramovich has taken the club to the top of the Premier League and into European football's elite. Why should they invest in older players with no re-sale value to make Conte look good over the next couple of years, instead of investing in the quality that will keep them at the top for the long term?\n\nThat said, Conte is also right in pointing to the fact that, with the investment at both Manchester clubs in particular, Chelsea may well have dragged their heels by leaving their summer business so late.\n\nIn fairness to both parties, the club were eighth, eight points off City when they were trounced 3-0 at Arsenal last September.\n\nThe pundits wrote them off for the title, the Alvaro Morata, Antonio Rudiger and Tiemoue Bakayoko to west London this summer.\n\nBut Conte has seen a number of departures from his first-team squad that won the Premier League last season, including Nemanja Matic, Nathan Ake and John Terry.\n\nAt last week's Premier League launch, Conte told Sky Sports News Chelsea's board know where he wants to strengthen the team and Azpilicueta says defender said.\n\n\"Obviously we have very good young players, but we have to know the reality that being champions is even harder the next season, we have experience of that.\n\n\"So we need players, also for the development of the young players, they need help from senior players, from top players, not to rush them in a position where maybe they are not ready to go at the moment but they will be in the future.\n\n\"So it is something that the club is working on with the manager, and hopefully we can get new signings in the next few weeks.\"\n\nThere seems to be no way back at Chelsea for the {"timeCrawl": "11:56:00", "uri": "709201423", "lang": "eng", "originalArticle": null, "dateTime": "2017-08-14T11:42:00Z", "sim": 0.4705882370471954, "source": {"title": "Evening Standard", "uri": "standard.co.uk", "id": "21"}, "url": "https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/chelsea-rebel-diego-costa-heaps-more-misery-on-antonio-conte-after-nightmare-start-to-title-defence-a3611321.html", "eventUri": "eng-3359141", "isDuplicate": false, "storyUri": "eng-3359141", "body": "Just when Chelsea's summer looked like it could not get any worse, Diego Costa decides to use the club and coach Antonio Conte for some target practice.\n\nThe rebel striker has shown over the past three years in England that he can inflict pain on many an opponent with a firm challenge or lethal finish, but his verbal attack is the last thing the Blues need now.\n\nCosta's interview in an English newspaper makes particularly grim reading for Conte, who is already reeling from a shock 3-2 opening-day defeat to Burnley at the weekend.\n\nThe Italian's man-management methods and handling of the 28-year-old's impending departure have come into question again, while Costa has also suggested there are senior players in the dressing room on his side.\n\nWhether the forward's version of events over his bitter divorce proceedings from the champions is completely accurate or not does not matter -- it has given everyone at Stamford Bridge a distraction they do not need.\n\nThis feels like another example of Chelsea not being in control of events on or off the pitch at the moment.\n\nAfter all, only on Friday it was explained that Conte could not talk about Costa in any detail because the situation is subject to a legal complaint. Yet 24 hours later the Spain international was giving chapter and verse to the Daily Mail.\n\nIt would not have had the same impact if the Blues had beaten Burnley. But now comparisons with the dreadful start to the 2015-16 campaign, when they went on to finish 10th and sacked former manager Jose Mourinho before Christmas, will only increase.\n\nJust as Conte has moaned about the club's dealings in the transfer market over the past few weeks after leading the team to the title, Mourinho was unhappy about their business in the summer window two years ago, having just guided them to the Premier League trophy himself.\n\nMourinho also fell out with Costa back then, although the striker has continued to deny it, and it had a negative impact on the pitch. However, at least he was in the capital, rather than thousands of miles away in Brazil as he is now.\n\nThe 2015 campaign began with Chelsea goalkeeper Thibaut Courtois getting sent off and the team dropping two points at home against unfancied opposition, although at least they scrambled a 2-2 draw with Swansea.\n\nConte's side managed to usurp the seriousness of that setback by having a couple of players shown the red card against Burnley and losing the game altogether.\n\nWith a depleted squad taking on Tottenham this Sunday, sources of optimism are few and far between.\n\nStill, at least they showed character in the final half-hour against Sean Dyche's side, coming back from three goals down and almost getting a draw with nine men.\n\nClub record buy Alvaro Morata's official debut off the bench was very encouraging, while Chelsea are still confident there will be four more arrivals before the end of the month. Vice-captain Cesar Azpilicueta has also offered cause for hope, namely that several members of the current dressing room were at Chelsea during the misery of 2015-16.\n\nThe Spain defender sees that as a help rather than a hindrance in their attempts to make sure history does not repeat itself.\n\nHe explained to Standard Sport: \"The players that were here two years ago know how difficult that season was, so with the experience we have of that, we have to learn from it and to change it.\n\n\"We know that a lot of teams have suffered after being champions. Not a lot of teams have won the League two years in a row in recent years. It is very difficult, so this is a big challenge for us.\n\n\"We know that everyone is going to try harder to beat us because we are the champions and were the best last season. It is something we have to take, and hopefully with our great experience of that from before, we can deal with it and turn things around.\"\n\nOne would think an away game against Spurs, their fiercest London rivals and a contender for the championship, would be the last thing the players would want now.\n\nBut Azpilicueta believes it provides the perfect remedy, adding: \"We know what a game against Tottenham means for all of us and the fans.\n\n\"It is a great moment when you come from a defeat to go there. We know that every game against them is a big game. It's a good match for us to turn back to winning ways. We know it is a difficult team, but I have no doubts we will work really hard to get into the best shape possible for Sunday.
